question_1: What is Kate Chopin message in The Awakening?
answert_1: The Awakening has been described as a case study of 19th-century feminism. One of the central themes in the novel is that of self-ownership. Also called bodily autonomy, self-ownership was a key tenet of 19th-century feminism. It signified a woman's right to have control over her own body and identity.
question_2: Is The Awakening A True story Kate Chopin?
answert_2: The Awakening was inspired by a true story of a New Orleans woman who was infamous in the French Quarter. Her first novel, At Fault, was published in 1890, followed by two collections of her short stories, Bayou Folk in 1894 and A Night in Acadia in 1897.
question_3: What does Edna say about dreams and sleep?
answert_3: The years that are gone seem like dreamsif one might go on sleeping and dreamingbut to wake up and findoh! well!
question_4: Was beginning to realize her position in the universe as a human being and to recognize her relations as an individual to the world within and about her?
answert_4: Pontellier was beginning to realize her position in the universe as a human being, and to recognize her relations as an individual to the world within and about her.
question_5: What is Chopin's message in The Awakening?
answert_5: Identity and Society's Expectations In Kate Chopin's The Awakening. In Kate Chopin's The Awakening, Edna Pontellier's suicide is an assertion of her independence and contributes to Chopin's message that to be independent one must choose between personal desires and societal expectations
question_6: What is Kate Chopins message?
answert_6: Chopin began writing fiction in 1889. She wrote about life and people in Louisiana and focused her attention on love, sex, marriage, women, and independence
question_7: What is the main purpose of The Awakening?
answert_7: The Awakening explores one woman's desire to find and live fully within her true self. Her devotion to that purpose causes friction with her friends and family, and also conflicts with the dominant values of her time. Edna Pontellier's story takes place in 1890s Louisiana, within the upper-class Creole society.
question_8: What do you think is Chopin's main message or theme about motherhood in The Awakening?
answert_8: In The Awakening by Kate Chopin, the theme of motherhood and the idea of the mother-woman, are both very prominent. The term mother-woman is used in The Awakening to describe society's image of the perfect woman; in other words, what Adele is, and what Edna is not. These women show more content
question_9: What inspired The Awakening by Kate Chopin?
answert_9: Chopin's own life, particularly in terms of having her own sense of identityaside from men and her childreninspired The Awakening. Her upbringing also shaped her views, as she lived with her widowed mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, all of whom were intellectual, independent women.
question_10: What is the meaning of The Awakening by Kate Chopin?
answert_10: The Awakening has been described as a case study of 19th-century feminism. One of the central themes in the novel is that of self-ownership. Also called bodily autonomy, self-ownership was a key tenet of 19th-century feminism. It signified a woman's right to have control over her own body and identity.
question_11: What does sleep symbolize in the awakening?
answert_11: Sleep: Sleep is an important symbolic motif running through the novel. Edna's moments of awakening are often preceded by sleep and she does a great deal of it. Sleep is also a means of escape and of repairing her tattered emotions
question_12: Why does Edna have trouble sleeping?
answert_12: The first night of the novel, Edna cannot sleep after being criticized by her husband for neglecting their children. It is during this sleepless night that her awakening begins. The first time she physically wakes up, she understands that she is oppressed.
question_13: What dream is Edna awakening from?
answert_13: In the end Edna becomes aware of her independence in reality and her dream of being with Robert shatters when he, like the other men in her life, wants to possess her. Her pursuit of independence causes her to see freedom only in death and leads to her suicide.
question_14: What does Edna value in the awakening?
answert_14: In her attempt to free herself from her suffocating life, Edna and the other characters in the book display their own personal American ideas and values in The Awakening. More than anything else, Edna Pontellier values the ideas of passionate love, and having the freedom to do what she wants
question_15: What does Edna realize about her relationship with her husband in Chapter 11?
answert_15: Summary: Chapter XI She can tell that her stubbornness irritates him, and she realizes that up to this point she has always submitted to her husband's requests unthinkingly, out of habit.
question_16: What does the lady in black foreshadow?
answert_16: The Lady in Black represents the dire consequences of shattering gender norms and social molds. Her dark and forbidding presence signifies what Edna ultimately discovers: that the price of individuality is dear. One that Edna pays with her life.
question_17: What does the lady in black symbolize in the awakening?
answert_17: The lady in black represents the conventional Victorian ideal of the widowed woman. Edna longs for independence from her husband, but the lady in black embodies the only such independence that society accepts in women: the patient, resigned solitude of a widow.
question_18: What is Mrs Pontellier's place in the universe?
answert_18: Pontellier was beginning to realize her position in the universe as a human being, and to recognize her relations as an individual to the world within and about her.
question_19: What does Chopin argue in The Awakening?
answert_19: The Awakening explores one woman's desire to find and live fully within her true self. Her devotion to that purpose causes friction with her friends and family, and also conflicts with the dominant values of her time. Edna Pontellier's story takes place in 1890s Louisiana, within the upper-class Creole society.
question_20: What is Edna trying to achieve throughout the novel?
answert_20: In The Awakening by Kate Chopin, the theme of motherhood and the idea of the mother-woman, are both very prominent. The term mother-woman is used in The Awakening to describe society's image of the perfect woman; in other words, what Adele is, and what Edna is not. These women show more content
question_21: What is Kate Chopin's message in The Story of an Hour?
answert_21: The Story of an Hour reflects Chopin's view of the repressive role that marriage played in women's lives as the protagonist, Louise Mallard, feels immense freedom only when her husband has died. While he is alive, she must live for him, and only when he dies does her life once again become her own.
question_22: What is Kate Chopin's message in the awakening?
answert_22: Identity and Society's Expectations In Kate Chopin's The Awakening. In Kate Chopin's The Awakening, Edna Pontellier's suicide is an assertion of her independence and contributes to Chopin's message that to be independent one must choose between personal desires and societal expectations
question_23: What was the purpose of The Awakening?
answert_23: The Awakening, novel by Kate Chopin, published in 1899. Originally titled A Solitary Soul, the novel depicts a young mother's struggle to achieve sexual and personal emancipation in the oppressive environment of the postbellum American South
question_24: What are the major themes of awakening?
answert_24:
Major Themes of The Awakening
  • Self vs Society. The novel criticizes the patriarchal society that deprives a woman of her freedom to think, feel and act as she pleases.
  • The power of societal conventions.
  • Feminism.
  • Birds.
  • The sea.
question_25: Why did Chopin write The Awakening?
answert_25: It was her obstetrician who knew of Kate's enormous energy and talent, who suggested she devote her time to writingboth for therapeutic and financial reasons. After a series of published short stories and a largely ignored first novel, Chopin wrote The Awakening.

question_1: How do I get Katakana keyboard on Android?
answert_1: Now, when you go to type text anywhere on your phone you'll see a little globe icon in the bottom left. Tap on that icon and it'll change to Japanese! You can see that it's worked by the text in the spacebar now saying u65e5u672cu8a9e. You can type in Hiragana, Katakana and Kanji.
question_2: How do I switch to Katakana keyboard?
answert_2: Ctrl + Caps Lock switch to Hiragana. Alt + Caps Lock if in alphanumeric mode change to Hiragana, then switch to Katakana.
question_3: Does Google keyboard have Katakana?
answert_3: Google Japanese Input only has 2 modes: kana/romaji. There is no hiragana-only/katakana-only compared to other IMEs. However, in kana mode, the suggestion box provides hiragana (normal/small), katakana (normal/small and full/half), kanji, and recently used words as possible conversion.
question_4: How can I write Katakana on my phone?
answert_4:
If you have an iPhone:
  • Begin on your home screen, and open your Settings app.
  • Scroll down and select General.
  • Scroll down and select Keyboards.
  • Once on the Keyboards screen, select Keyboards again.
  • Select Add New Keyboard at the bottom of the screen.
  • Scroll down to Japanese.
    • Feb 2, 2017
question_5: How do I download Katakana keyboard?

question_6: How do I turn on Japanese keyboard on Android?
answert_6:
If you have an iPhone:
  • Begin on your home screen, and open your Settings app.
  • Scroll down and select General.
  • Scroll down and select Keyboards.
  • Once on the Keyboards screen, select Keyboards again.
  • Select Add New Keyboard at the bottom of the screen.
  • Scroll down to Japanese.

question_1: What is the easiest way to memorize katakana?
answert_1: But how to remember them? The best, quickest, most fun method is to associate each character with a picture that it (clearly or vaguely) looks like, ideally also using the sound of the letter. Hiragana and katakana are pretty simple, so associating each character with a picture is super easy.
question_2: What is the easiest way to memorize Hiragana and Katakana?
answert_2: It takes about 2 weeks to teach the phonology slowly, plus testing and review. Katakana is usually introduced far later and takes maybe a week, but there's no reason why you can't do them at the same time.
question_3: How long does it take to memorize katakana?
answert_3: In terms of what you're learning, it will be very simple. Katakana is, for the most part, the same sounds you learned with hiragana. But, the characters representing those sounds are different. It would be like if in English you replaced the letter A with the symbol u30a2 without changing how it's used and pronounced.
question_4: How can I memorize katakana fast?
answert_4: It takes about 2 weeks to teach the phonology slowly, plus testing and review. Katakana is usually introduced far later and takes maybe a week, but there's no reason why you can't do them at the same time.
question_5: How can I memorize Japanese fast?
answert_5: But how to remember them? The best, quickest, most fun method is to associate each character with a picture that it (clearly or vaguely) looks like, ideally also using the sound of the letter. Hiragana and katakana are pretty simple, so associating each character with a picture is super easy.
question_6: What is the easiest way to memorize hiragana?
answert_6: Mnemonics: Due to hiragana's relative simplicity (at least compared to kanji), image-based mnemonics are a perfect method for memorization. Each hiragana character has a memorable illustration that goes along with it. For a long time I believed that mnemonics were a waste of time.
question_7: What's the best way to learn hiragana and katakana?
answert_7: Write each one a few times, in order. Then cover them up (or just turn over the paper) and try writing them again. Do this a few times a day, at least once or twice every hour or so. Hiragana and Katakana are easy enough that you can power through them.
question_8: Should I memorize hiragana and katakana first?
answert_8: The use of katakana is limited to only certain words, so it'd be more helpful to start with hiragana. IF you are going to Japan anytime soon, though, I'd recommend learning katakana first since you would be able to read a lot more things knowing it (especially menus and stuff!)
question_9: Which is easier to learn katakana or Hiragana?
answert_9: Hiragana and katakana are similar writing systems, so studying hiragana is a much easier way to learn katakana too. Hiragana is the basic.
question_10: How hard is it to learn katakana?
answert_10: The number of katakana is the same as Hiragana which is used the most in writing. Compared with Kanji ( Chinese character ), which is difficult even for Japanese people, katakana is relatively easy to master
question_11: How long does it take to memorize Japanese?
answert_11: According to the US Department of State, Japanese is one of the hardest languages for English natives to learn. It doesn't have many similarities in structure to English. They estimate it takes 88 weeks of learning, or 2200 hours, to reach fluency.
question_12: When should you start learning katakana?
answert_12: In fact, we recommend that beginners learn katakana as soon as possible. Ideally you will learn hiragana first, and then move on to katakana straight after! These two scripts will be an essential foundation in your journey to learn Japanese.

question_14: Can Japanese people have katakana names?
answert_14: Absolutely. Katakana is a valid part of Japanese writing, and can be used for names as well as other purposes. When I first went to Japan, I lodged in a home in Osaka.
question_15: Can Japanese people read Japanese in English letters?
answert_15: Yes, easily. Writing in this way is called romaji. They are taught how to use English to write Japanese words from primary school. In fact most Japanese enter Japanese text into PCs by using English spelling in a qwerty keyboard.
question_16: Can I live in Japan only knowing hiragana and katakana?
answert_16: Based on experience of friends of mine, who lived there for a year: yes you can. It is better to know the kanji too, but you can do the everyday stuff without kanji. One of them (the less proficient Japanese speaker) recommended both hiragana and katakana though, not just hiragana.

question_20: Is it okay to learn only hiragana?

As a consequence, if you start learning katakana first, you will still need some knowledge of hiragana or kanji before you can understand some texts.

question_1: Why is Kat so important to the group of soldiers?
answert_1: Kat, as he is affectionately known, is famed amongst the men for his resourcefulness, able to scrounge up food in the remotest of places. This usefulness makes him loved by and invaluable to the other soldiers.
question_2: Does Kat die in All Quiet on the Western Front?
answert_2: After Kat dies from a shrapnel splinter in the head, the loss of Militiaman Stanislaus Katczinsky seems all the more intolerable, as though the final prop has been knocked from beneath Paul, leaving him defenseless in the face of the interminable war.
question_3: What is Kat known for who is his helper?
answert_3: Haie Westhus: A giant boy about 19, he is a peat-digger by trade. He is Kat's main helper.
question_4: What is Kat's opinion of war?
answert_4: What is Kat's opinion of war? He thinks it is pointless.
question_5: Why is Kat so important to his fellow soldiers?
answert_5: Lesson Summary At about 40 years old, Kat is the father figure and leader for many of the younger men. He helps out his younger comrades -- fellow soldiers -- and teaches them many things about how to survive in war.
question_6: How do Kropp and Kat feel about the people in charge of the war?
answert_6: The author contrasts Kat with Kropp who is a thinker Kropp suggests that the War should be fought by the countries'generals. He feels that the wrong people do the fighting. The group disses drilling and structure and the lunacy of the skills they were taught in boot camp. Those skills are useless to them now.
question_7: What advice did Kat give the new soldiers?
answert_7: Kat gives the soldier some food, telling him that next time, he should bring tobacco to trade if he wants more food, and then shares the food with Paul and his friends for free.
question_8: What did Kat do before the war?
answert_8: Kat has the most positive influence on Paul and his comrades on the battlefield. Katczinsky was a cobbler in civilian life; he is older than Paul Bxe4umer and his comrades, about 40 years old, and serves as their leadership figure.
question_9: Who dies in All Quiet on the Western Front?
answert_9: Kemmerich is a young man and a member of Paul, the narrator's, unit in the army. At the beginning of the novel, Kemmerich is dying in the hospital. Kemmerich suffers a terrible injury and loses his leg, dying horribly and painfully at the end of Chapter 2.
question_10: How does Kat die and how does Paul try to save him?
answert_10: Kat is wounded while returning with food that he has scavenged. Paul cannot leave him to find a stretcher because Kat is bleeding too much. Paul painstakingly carries him to the dressing station while shells crash around him.
question_11: What happens to Kat and how does this affect Paul?
answert_11: Unfortunately, Kat sustains another injuryshrapnel in his brainwhile Paul is carrying him and dies almost instantly. This death is among the most shocking for Paul; he had assumed his friend was only slightly wounded. Perhaps partially as a result of Kat's senseless and sudden death, Paul dies shortly thereafter.
question_12: What happens to Muller Bertinck Leer and Kat?
answert_12: What happens to Muller, Bertinck, Leer, and Kat? Muller - he is shot point blank in the stomach; Bertinck - is wounded in the chest when he gets out of the hole to use his rifle to take down the flamethrowers. He shoots the one and then the other gets burned by the flamethrower without his partner to help control it.
question_13: What is Kat known for?
answert_13: Kat, as he is affectionately known, is famed amongst the men for his resourcefulness, able to scrounge up food in the remotest of places. This usefulness makes him loved by and invaluable to the other soldiers.
question_14: Who is Katczinsky Kat )? Why is he so important to Paul and his friends?
answert_14: Stanislaus 'Kat'Katczinsky is one of the older men serving in the war for Germany. At about 40 years old, Kat is the father figure and leader for many of the younger men. He helps out his younger comrades -- fellow soldiers -- and teaches them many things about how to survive in war.
question_15: What are Kat's and Kropp's ideas about war?
answert_15: Kat believes that if every soldier got the same food and the same pay, the war would end quickly. Kropp proposes that the declaration of wars should be conducted like a festival.
question_16: How does Kropp think wars should be fought?
answert_16: The author contrasts Kat with Kropp who is a thinker Kropp suggests that the War should be fought by the countries'generals. He feels that the wrong people do the fighting. The group disses drilling and structure and the lunacy of the skills they were taught in boot camp. Those skills are useless to them now.
question_17: What special ability does Kat have?
answert_17: Kat, as he is affectionately known, is famed amongst the men for his resourcefulness, able to scrounge up food in the remotest of places. This usefulness makes him loved by and invaluable to the other soldiers.
question_18: How does Kropp feel about the war?
answert_18: Kropp reminds the cook that rules are of no use when survival is on the line. Kropp on the other hand is a thinker. He proposes that a declaration of war should be a kind of popular festival with entrance-tickets and bands, like a bull-fight.
question_19: What does Kat think about the war?
answert_19: What the army leaders see as discipline, Kat sees as pointless. He believes that the leaders of the war are simply prolonging the effort because they have more power than the typical soldier, and that if everyone had 'the same grub and the same pay,'the war would be over much more quickly.
question_20: What is Remarque saying about men at war?
answert_20: Remarque says that this novel will try simply to tell of a generation of men who, even though they may have escaped shells, were destroyed by the war. If words can touch what men hold to be dear in their hearts and so cause them to change the world, this book with its words of a lost generation, lost values, and lost
question_21: What does Kat Katczinsky give the new recruits of second company?
answert_21: More than twenty of the reinforcements for the Second Company are only about seventeen years old. Kat gives one of the new recruits some beans that he acquired by bribing the company's cook. He warns the boy to bring tobacco next time as payment for the food.
question_22: What does Kat teach Paul?
answert_22: The Friendship of Kat and Paul Paul's relationship with his own father is strained, but Kat takes on the role of Paul's father by teaching Paul how to survive the war. 'Paul outright says that he loves Kat, who feeds him, teaches him, and keeps him safe. During a battle later in the novel, Kat is wounded.
question_23: What is Kats theory?
answert_23: Schrxf6dinger's cat: a cat, a flask of poison, and a radioactive source are placed in a sealed box. The Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics implies that after a while, the cat is simultaneously alive and dead. Yet, when one looks in the box, one sees the cat either alive or dead, not both alive and dead.
question_24: What was Kat's occupation before the war?
answert_24: Kat's life as a poor farmer has given him the experience needed to survive hard times, and he is counted on to find food and supplies where none seem to be available.
question_25: What is Katczinsky job outside of the war?

question_1: What is the theme of A Respectable Woman by Kate Chopin?
answert_1: The main themes of the short story A Respectable Woman by Kate Chopin are identity and desire versus restraint. The theme of identity is enhanced through motifs such as perception and appearances because the story tends to follow the way the protagonist perceives herself and Gouvernail.
question_2: Is Mrs Baroda A Respectable Woman?
answert_2: Baroda; she is A Respectable Woman and therefore should not give into her unladylike thoughts. In the beginning of the story, the reader began to distrust Mrs. Baroda as a character because she seemed to have no rhyme or reason to why she liked Mr. Gouvernail and so fiercely disliked him at the same time.
question_3: Who is the main character of A Respectable Woman?
answert_3: The most important character in the short story A Respectable Woman by Kate Chopin is the protagonist, Mrs.Baroda whose perspective the narrator employs.
question_4: Why is Mrs Baroda attracted to Gouvernail?
answert_4: Mrs Baroda appears to be attracted to Gouvernail however she is able to resist her urges to touch Gouvernail's face due to her belief that she is a respectable woman (and possibly out of fear of what society may think of her). Mrs Baroda appears to be restricted to society's opinion of what a respectable woman may be.
question_5: What is the central conflict of the story A Respectable Woman?
answert_5: The short story A Respectable Woman by Kate Chopin is structured around the character of Mrs. Baroda and her inner conflict as she finds herself attracted to her husband's friend. The story follows the elements of a traditional plot: exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution.
question_6: What is the tone of A Respectable Woman?
answert_6: The most important character in the short story A Respectable Woman by Kate Chopin is the protagonist, Mrs.Baroda whose perspective the narrator employs.
question_7: What type of character is Mrs Baroda?
answert_7: Baroda first comes across as a woman with preconceived ideas, as she expects the man to be in a certain way and she is proven wrong: But she had unconsciously formed an image of him in her mind. She pictured him tall, slim, cynical; with eye-glasses, and his hands in his pockets; and she did not like him.
question_8: Who is Mrs Baroda?
answert_8: Baroda, a rich woman with a loving husband who encounters temptation in the person of Gouvernail, a well-mannered, humble visitor to the Baroda's plantation. Mrs. Baroda is tempted early in the story with the view of a change from a noiseless, more conventional life, Mrs.
question_9: Why does Mrs Baroda not like Gouvernail at first?
answert_9: Mrs. Baroda after wants to disclose her feelings of love towards Gouvernail to her husband but she drops this idea because she is a respectable woman not only in the eyes of society but also in the eyes of her husband. She has no courage to break it.
question_10: What did Mrs Baroda want?
answert_10: Baroda want to do? Give Gouvernail a kiss.
question_11: Who are the characters in A Respectable Woman?
answert_11:
Kate Chopin: A Respectable Woman
  • Mrs. Baroda.
  • Gouvernail: journalist, a college friend of Mrs. Baroda's husband. His name in French means a rudder, a tiller, with the implication that he is someone who knows the direction, who understands where things are headed.
  • Gaston Baroda: Mrs. Baroda's husband.
question_12: Why does Mrs Baroda like Gouvernail?
answert_12: Baroda; she is A Respectable Woman and therefore should not give into her unladylike thoughts. In the beginning of the story, the reader began to distrust Mrs. Baroda as a character because she seemed to have no rhyme or reason to why she liked Mr. Gouvernail and so fiercely disliked him at the same time.
question_13: What characteristics does Mrs Baroda associate with being a woman?
answert_13: Baroda wanted Gouvernail to pay attention to her which he did not. He loved loneliness and his solitary habits. Therefore, to draw his attention towards her, Mrs. Baroda tried to change his solitary habits by giving him company in his idle strolls to the mill and walks along the river.
question_14: Why does Mrs Baroda not disclose her feelings towards Gouvernail to her husband?
answert_14: u279c Mrs Baroda does not disclose her feelings towards Gouvernail to her husband because she appears to be restricted to society's opinion. Her fear of what society might think of her and her perception that she is a respectable woman prevented Mrs Baroda from telling her husband about her emotions for Gouvernail.
question_15: Why was Mrs Baroda upset that Gouvernail was coming to stay with her?
answert_15: Short Summary: Mrs Baroda finds that Gouvernail, her husband's friend, is staying with them on their plantation. She is dissatisfied by this because they had been having a lot of fun and she had hoped for a break. She'd never met the man but had heard a lot of good things about him.
question_16: How was Gouvernail different from Mrs Baroda's expectation?
answert_16: Gouvernall was different from Mrs Baroda's expectation as she imagined him to be tall, thin, and cynical, wearing eyeglasses but when she met him, he was neither tall nor cynical. She didn't believe him as smart and clever but her mental sketch was totally different when she met her.
question_17: What does the reader learn about Mrs Baroda when Gouvernail opens up to her?
answert_17: Mrs. Baroda was a little provoked1 to learn that her husband expected his friend, Gouvernail, up to spend a week or two on the plantation. He had been her husband's college friend; was now a journalist, and in no sense a society man or a man about town, which were, perhaps, some of the reasons she had never met him.
question_18: What is the conflict in the story A Respectable Woman?
answert_18: The short story A Respectable Woman by Kate Chopin is structured around the character of Mrs. Baroda and her inner conflict as she finds herself attracted to her husband's friend. answert_20: The main cause of conflict in Mrs. Baroda's mind is her romantic feeling towards Gouvernail, the friend of her husband. Her personal desire urges her to express her feelings for Gouvernail but she is not allowed to do so by the social rules.
question_21: What is the setting of the story A Respectable Woman?
answert_21: The story takes place on Gaston Baroda's sugar plantation in Louisiana, apparently in the 1880s or early 1890s.

question_23: What does it mean to be A Respectable Woman?
answert_23: 1 having or deserving the respect of other people; estimable; worthy. 2 having good social standing or reputation. 3 having socially or conventionally acceptable morals, standards, etc. a respectable woman. 4 relatively or fairly good; considerable.

question_1: Is katakana a spoken language?
answert_1: If you go by sound, then yes. Hiragana and Katakana consist of 46 regular sounds each and are the same when they are spoken aloud.
question_2: What is difference between Hiragana and Katakana?
answert_2: The major difference between hiragana and katakana is the fact that hiragana is primarily used to represent Japanese words, while katakana represents foreign words. Japanese is a language with many borrowed words, and katakana immediately alerts the reader to the fact that the word is an imported one.
question_3: What are the 46 katakana letters?
answert_3: vowelsu30a2 au30a6 um-lineu30de mau30e0 muy-lineu30e4 yau30e6 yur-lineu30e9 rau30eb ruw-lineu30ef wa6 more rows
question_4: Is katakana just English?
answert_4: A word is written in katakana when it is from a different language so all words that has come from countries like Portugal and France will be written in Katakana. So yes, there are lots of words that are written in katakana which is not from English
question_5: Where is katakana spoken?
answert_5: Unlike the Hiragana system (used for Japanese words the Kanji doesn't cover), the Katakana writing system is used for foreign language transcription into Japanese and for writing loan words, or gairaigo.
question_6: Do Japanese speak katakana or Hiragana?
answert_6: JapaneseWriting systemMixed scripts of Kanji (Chinese character) and Kana (Hiragana, Katakana) Japanese BrailleSigned formsSigned JapaneseOfficial statusOfficial language inJapan (de facto) Palau (on Angaur Island)15 more rows
question_7: Can Japanese speak without katakana?
answert_7: The short answer is: yes, you can speak fluent Japanese and understand Japanese people without ever studying a single kanji. In fact, if you focus your studies on hearing comprehension, it's likely that you will achieve fluency of speech much faster than somebody who chooses to focus on kanji.
question_8: Is it better to learn hiragana or katakana?
answert_8: The use of katakana is limited to only certain words, so it'd be more helpful to start with hiragana. IF you are going to Japan anytime soon, though, I'd recommend learning katakana first since you would be able to read a lot more things knowing it (especially menus and stuff!)
question_9: Do Japanese use katakana or hiragana?
answert_9: In a sense, hiragana is the most commonly used, standard form of Japanese writing. Japanese vocabulary usually tends to be written in hiragana as opposed to katakana. Also, hiragana is used to write furigana, a reading aid that shows the pronunciation of kanji characters, which is sure to be helpful.
question_10: What is harder to learn hiragana or katakana?
answert_10: The kana are easy to learn. You can learn katakana just as easily as you have learned hiragana. Now, again, you will forget these if you don't use them, so keep practicing occasionally to keep them in mind even after you learn them.
question_11: What are the 46 hiragana?
answert_11: vowelsu3042 au3046 uh-lineu306f hau3075 fum-lineu307e mau3080 muy-lineu3084 yau3086 yur-lineu3089 rau308b ru6 more rows
question_12: How many katakana letters are there?
answert_12: The complete katakana script consists of 48 characters, not counting functional and diacritic marks: 5 nucleus vowels.
question_13: What is the basic alphabet of Japan with 47 characters?
answert_13: Hiragana, Katakana, and Kanji: Defining the Differences Hiragana and katakana collectively referred to by the generic term kanamoji are both syllabic alphabets of 47 characters, each of which represents a sound.
question_14: How many katakana are there in Japanese?
answert_14: In modern Japanese, there are 46 basic Katakana letters. In addition to these 46 basic letters called goju016bon, there are modified forms to describe more sounds - 20 dakuon, 5 handakuon, 36 ydon, 1 sokuon and 6 additional letters.
question_15: Are all Katakana words from English?
answert_15: Many Japanese think that the origin of the majority Katakana words are English, but it's not always true. It could be French, German, Spanish or even just made up made-in-Japan Katakana words. So you might be confused when you hear the Japanese speak such Katakana words with confidence.
question_16: Is Katakana for foreign words?
answert_16: In modern Japanese, katakana is most often used for transcription of words from foreign languages or loanwords (other than words historically imported from Chinese), called gairaigo.
question_17: Can you write Japanese with only Katakana?
answert_17: It is actually possible to write anything in Japanese using only Hiragana and Katakana which are the phonetic systems.
question_18: Do Japanese people speak Katakana or hiragana?
answert_18: Japanese language.JapaneseNative speakers~128 million (2020)Language familyJaponic Japanese17 more rows
question_19: Where do they speak katakana?
answert_19: Kanji is the oldest and is a picture-based system from China made up of logograms, which are characters that represent whole words. Hiragana and katakana are native to Japan and represent syllable sounds; together these two alphabets are referred to as kana.
question_20: Do Japanese Learn katakana?
answert_20: If you go by sound, then yes. Hiragana and Katakana consist of 46 regular sounds each and are the same when they are spoken aloud.
question_21: Do Japanese speak hiragana?
answert_21: The use of katakana is limited to only certain words, so it'd be more helpful to start with hiragana. IF you are going to Japan anytime soon, though, I'd recommend learning katakana first since you would be able to read a lot more things knowing it (especially menus and stuff!)
question_22: Can I learn Japanese without katakana?
answert_22: Assuming you are a non-Japanese, you would be well advised to learn hiragana and katakana (in that order). Learning them is trivial, and the language and its spelling (excluding kanji of course) are completely phonetic and much easier than English spelling.
question_23: Can I learn Japanese without hiragana and katakana?
answert_23: Besides, mastering it requires a long learning process. Well, the truth is that you can learn Japanese without kanji. You can just concentrate on learning hiragana and katakana. This is because as long as you have a good understanding of hiragana and katakana, you can communicate to an extent in Japanese.
question_24: Is it OK to learn Japanese without kanji?
answert_24: The short answer is: yes, you can speak fluent Japanese and understand Japanese people without ever studying a single kanji. In fact, if you focus your studies on hearing comprehension, it's likely that you will achieve fluency of speech much faster than somebody who chooses to focus on kanji.
question_25: Can you learn Japanese with only hiragana?
answert_25: Yes, you can learn only hiragana without learning kanji and katakana. However, you must understand that learning only hiragana will limit your understanding of the Japanese language to a very large extent. In fact, you cannot read the majority of the things that are written in Japanese.

question_1: Who was better Karna or Arjun?
answert_1: Though abandoned at childhood, Karna had a far better life than Arjuna which he threw away himself because he sided with adharma. Karna had made his life's mission to prove himself to Arjuna that he was the greatest of all warriors. He made it into a personal battle.
question_2: Why is Karna great?
answert_2: Karna was the closest friend of Duryodhana and fought on his behalf against the Pandavas in the famous Kurukshetra war. Karna fought against misfortune throughout his life and kept his word under all circumstances. Many admire him for his courage and generosity
question_3: Who is Karna wife in Mahabharata?
answert_3: Vrushali
question_4: What did Karna do wrong?
answert_4: Karna was cursed by Rishi Parusharam even though he was aware of his true heritage. Rishi Parusharam cursed Karna for deceiving him. Karna had claimed he was a Brahmin, which was a lie. He had lied so that he could learn archery from the greatest teacher of all time
question_5: Was Arjuna more powerful than Karna?
answert_5: Karna is better than Arjuna as a warrior. As an archer, he was superior to Arjuna: Lord Krishna considered Karna to be superior to Arjuna and called the foremost of all heroes.
question_6: Was Karna better archer than Arjuna?
answert_6: Out of Karna and Arjuna as archer both are at par. Karna being elder finally admired Arjuna as the top archer. Arjuna did question Lord Krishna to attack Karna when he was weapon less and below the chariot quite busy in outing the wheel.
question_7: Did Karna ever defeat Arjuna?
answert_7: Unfortunately, Karna never defeated Arjuna in a direct battle. He was always defeated by the latter and he fled away most of the times. To be honest, Karna was nowhere near the league of Arjuna. He was powerful but not as powerful as Arjuna.
question_8: Why is Karna more popular than Arjuna?
answert_8: Why is Karna more popular than Arjuna? Karna faces many struggles in his early age then get recognition with is skills. He has a great respect on friendship which is the fatal flaw made him to die. His character gained more sympathetic which made popular in this epic.
question_9: Why was Karna so great?
answert_9: Karna was a loyal and great friend of Suyodhana. He was completely devoted to him since Duryodhana was the one because of whom he became the ruler of Anga. Karna also worked for Duryodhana's welfare and always did what pleased him the most. He was a part of all the evil schemes of Duyodhana and never opposed them.
question_10: Why Karna was better than Arjuna?
answert_10: Though abandoned at childhood, Karna had a far better life than Arjuna which he threw away himself because he sided with adharma. All his weapons were given to him by his Guru while Arjuna dealt with a lot of penance and worshipped devoutly to obtain his own arms.
question_11: What are the good qualities of Karna?
answert_11: Generosity or kindness is the greatest quality of Karna. If a dictionary needs a substitute for those words the name Karna is adequate. His other good qualities include: Loyalty (towards Duryodhan).
question_12: Is Karna a good?
answert_12: Karna was a great warrior. When Pandavas'13 years of Vanavas was over, Karna took a vow to donate anything until he kills Arjuna in the war. He stood by it even at testing times. These are good qualities of Karna.
question_13: Who is Karna real wife?
answert_13: In many recent adaptations of the Mahabharata, Karna is married to two womenVrushali and Supriya.
question_14: Who is Karna Favourite wife?
answert_14: The folklore name is Vrushali, the most devoted wife to Karna, his first wife who burnt herself on her husband's pyre after he perished. She was the sister of Satyasen, Duryodhana's charioteer. She was chosen by the foster parents of Karna for him.
question_15: Who did Karna Love?
answert_15: According to one of the versions, there lived a princess named Uruvi, who fell in love with Karna after seeing him in the court of Dhrupad. She was the daughter of Kunti's friend Subhra. Apparently, the princess'parents wanted her to marry Arjun, but she chose Karna instead.
question_16: What was Karna's fault?
answert_16: Mistake of letting his pride kill his honour sense of good and bad. He knew that Duryodhan was wrong but he kept supporting him. He knew that Pandavas were right, but his anger that Draupadi didn't chose him. His anger that whatever he was denied Arjuna got.
question_17: What are the bad things that Karna did?
answert_17: He was evil enough to take part in duryodhana's evil conspiracies and harassing draupadi. But he was good enough to realise and apologize for his mistakes and reject the throne offered by lord krishna to get the punishment for his evil deeds.
question_18: Is Karna was bad?
answert_18: When Pandavas'13 years of Vanavas was over, Karna took a vow to donate anything until he kills Arjuna in the war. He stood by it even at testing times. These are good qualities of Karna. To answer in short, he was a good person in bad company
question_19: Was Karna right or wrong?
answert_19: Karna was never right. He participated in all the wrong deeds of Duryodhana despite knowing that he was wrong. He still was in the side of Duryodhana inspite of knowing that the Pandavas were right because Lord Krishna was by their side.
question_20: Was Karna stronger than Arjuna?
answert_20: Arjuna destroyed Karna in Virat Yuddha. , Interested in Indian epics. Arjuna was better warrior then Karna
question_21: Why was Arjuna better than Karna?
answert_21: The only way, Arjuna was better than Karna, is the support of Great People like Krishna, Bhisma, Drona and Kriba. Also, he wasnt fortified by his mother either. They both were equal in almost every other dept. In fact, Karna was better.
question_22: Who was better in archery Karna or Arjuna?
answert_22: Lord Krishna also agrees that Karna is superior to Arjuna in archery,and understands that Arjuna will not be able to slay him due to various boons and better skills.
question_23: Was Karna superior to Arjuna?
answert_23: Karna killed only some hundreds of gandharvas in the battle of ghosh yatra. Whereas Arjuna killed one million gandharvas within an instant in the same battle. Thus Arjuna was superior to Karna in prowess. Most importantly, Arjuna was able to rescue the Kurus, which Karna couldn't.
question_24: How many times Karna defeated Arjuna?
answert_24: Arjuna defeated Karna twice before the great war of kurukshetra. He defeated once directly and once indirectly.
question_25: Who wins between Arjun and Karna?
answert_25: Karna is better than Arjuna as a warrior. As an archer, he was superior to Arjuna: Lord Krishna considered Karna to be superior to Arjuna and called the foremost of all heroes.

question_1: What is the theme of shark girl?
answert_1: Depression. After losing her arm following a shark attack, Jane is understandably depressed. This depression is amplified by the fact that she is in constant pain, and can no longer draw or cook since she lost her dominant hand. Evidence of her depression floods the narrative.
question_2: What happens at the end of the book Shark Girl?
answert_2: Looking through old photo albums of her dad before he died from cancer, Jane realizes the trick to life is celebrating the freedom of not knowing what will happen next. She says goodbye to her arm and starts to look forward to her future, beginning a new photo album of her new life with only one arm.
question_3: What is the theme of shark girl by Kelly Bingham?
answert_3: What about her life? In this striking first novel, Kelly Bingham uses poems, letters, telephone conversations, and newspaper clippings to look unflinchingly at what it's like to lose part of yourself - and to summon the courage it takes to find yourself again.
question_4: Who is the antagonist in shark girl?

question_5: What is the setting of shark girl?
answert_5: Shark Girl (2007) is the debut novel by Kelly Bingham. It is a young adult novel in verse that tells the story of the fifteen-year-old Jane Arrowood who goes swimming at a California beach in June, is attacked by a shark and has to have her right arm amputated.
question_6: How old is justin in shark girl?
answert_6: Sharing Jane's journey is Justin a ten year old boy who lost his leg and was in the hospital during the same time period. Justin's innocence and forthright way of dealing with loss help Jane cope.

answert_8: The novel is told mostly through blank verse poetry that is interspersed with news articles about Jane's attack and letters of encouragement she receives from strangers. question_1: Is a dolphin a fish?
answert_1: Even though they live in the ocean all of the time, dolphins are mammals, not fish. Like every mammal, dolphins are warm blooded. Unlike fish, who breathe through gills, dolphins breathe air using lungs. They are the only mammals, other than manatees, that spend their entire lives in the water.
question_2: Is a dolphin a shark or a fish?
answert_2: The first difference between sharks and dolphins is the type of animal they are sharks are fish while dolphins are mammals (like us). Dolphins, and other mammals, are warm blooded, give birth to live young, nurse their young, are born with hair, and breathe air.
question_3: Why is dolphin a mammal and shark a fish?
answert_3: Specifically, sharks are fish, meaning they have gills, breathe underwater and are cold-blooded. On the other hand, dolphins are mammals, much like humans, meaning they breathe air, are warm-blooded, and nurse their offspring.
question_4: Are dolphins carnivores?
answert_4: Dolphins are highly intelligent marine mammals and are part of the family of toothed whales that includes orcas and pilot whales. They are found worldwide, mostly in shallow seas of the continental shelves, and are carnivores, mostly eating fish and squid.
question_5: Do dolphins lay eggs or give birth?
answert_5: The first difference between sharks and dolphins is the type of animal they are sharks are fish while dolphins are mammals (like us). Dolphins, and other mammals, are warm blooded, give birth to live young, nurse their young, are born with hair, and breathe air.
question_6: Is a whale a fish?
answert_6: Like every mammal, dolphins are warm blooded. Other characteristics of dolphins that make them mammals rather than fish are that they give birth to live young rather than laying eggs and they feed their young with milk. Also, like all mammals, dolphins even have a tiny amount of hair, right around the blowhole.
question_7: How are dolphins are different from fishes?
answert_7: Whales, along with dolphins and porpoises, are warm-blooded mammals and breathe air like humans do. There are some significant differences between whales and fish: Fish use gills to extract air from water. Whales give birth to live young.
question_8: Is Dolphin a shark?
answert_8: The first difference between sharks and dolphins is the type of animal they are sharks are fish while dolphins are mammals (like us). Dolphins and sharks both have dorsal fins on their backs, two pectoral fins on their sides, and a tail.
question_9: Is a shark whale or dolphin a fish?
answert_9: Sharks are fish. Dolphins are part of the Cetacean family, which also includes whales and porpoises. Like other mammals, dolphins are warm blooded, have some hair or fur, give birth to live young and nurse their young.
question_10: Why is Dolphin a mammal and shark a fish?
answert_10: Specifically, sharks are fish, meaning they have gills, breathe underwater and are cold-blooded. On the other hand, dolphins are mammals, much like humans, meaning they breathe air, are warm-blooded, and nurse their offspring.
question_11: Is dolphin a fish or a meat?
answert_11: Cooked dolphin meat has a flavor very similar to beef liver. Dolphin meat is high in mercury, and may pose a health danger to humans when consumed. Ringed seals were once the main food staple for the Inuit. They are still an important food source for the people of Nunavut and are also hunted and eaten in Alaska.
question_12: Why is a shark a fish and not a mammal?
answert_12: Sharks Are Not Mammals They don't produce milk, they don't have hair, and most of them are cold-blooded. The only characteristic they share with mammals is that some shark species give live birth.
question_13: Are dolphins and sharks fish?
answert_13: The first difference between sharks and dolphins is the type of animal they are sharks are fish while dolphins are mammals (like us). Another fact about sharks is that they are what are known as cartilaginous fish, meaning their skeletons are made of cartilage (like our ears and noses) rather than dense bone.
question_14: Is a shark a fish and a mammal?
answert_14: Sharks are fish, even though some people believe they are mammals due to how big some of them can get and because some give birth to live young. Fish are aquatic animals that were among the first vertebrates (animals with a backbone) to evolve on earth.
question_15: Are dolphins carnivores yes or no?
answert_15: The bottlenose dolphin enjoys a variety of tasty meals. They tend to feast on multiple kinds of fish, squid, and crustaceans (including shrimp and crabs). Dolphins are carnivorous marine animals
question_16: Do dolphins eat humans?
answert_16: No, dolphins do not eat people. While the killer whale can be observed eating fish, squid, and octopus along with large animals such as sea lions, seals, walruses, penguins, dolphins (yes, they eat dolphins), and whales, they do not appear to have any desire towards eating humans.
question_17: Why are dolphins carnivores?
answert_17: Dolphins have 100 teeth in their mouth. Despite large number of teeth, they don't chew their food - they swallow their prey in one piece. All dolphins are carnivores (meat-eaters). Smaller dolphins eat fish and squids, while large dolphins like orca eat seals, sea lions and other type of dolphins and whales.
question_18: Do dolphins eat meat?
answert_18: Toothed whales (including all dolphins) are carnivores; they eat other animals. Dolphins eat a variety of fish, squid, shrimps, jellyfish and octopuses.
question_19: How does a dolphin give birth?
answert_19: Calves are born in the water. Deliveries are usually tail-first, but head-first deliveries are also seen. The umbilical cord snaps during delivery. Sometimes an assisting dolphin may stay close to the new mother and calf.
question_20: How do dolphins lay their eggs?
answert_20: Dolphins give birth to live young and do not lay eggs. They can get pregnant on average every two to four years once they're mature, although some species can have 5-7 years between births.
question_21: Why do dolphins not lay eggs?
answert_21: Whales and dolphins are mammals. This means that they are warm-blooded, and have to maintain their own body temperature. They have hair (at least a little), give live birth to their young and to provide them with milk from the mother's mammary glands, and they must breathe air.
question_22: Can a human give birth to a dolphin?
answert_22: To make it possible for a human mother to deliver a dolphin from her womb, there is a need to synthesise The Dolp-human Placenta. The placenta originates from the baby's side, which in this case is a dolphin, and not from the human side.
question_23: Can a whale be classified as a fish?
answert_23: Whales are a member of the cetacean family, and as such, despite being wholly water-resident, whales are mammals, not fish.
question_24: Is a whale a fish or a reptile?
answert_24: Whales are mammals. They look somewhat like large fish but are not closely related to them. Whales belong to the taxonomic infraorder Cetacea.
question_25: What is a whale classified as?
answert_25: Mammalia

question_1: Is Shantaram a true story?
answert_1: David Gregory Roberts calls Shantaram a novel, but it is strongly autobiographical, concentrating on his life in Bombay from 1981 to 1987. Some characters have been disguised or blended, but he insists that the key events are authentic.
question_2: What happens at the end of Shantaram?

question_1: What is shape tween and why do we use it?
answert_1: Shape Tweens are used to morph between Merge Shapes and Drawing Objects. Shape tweens appear in the timeline as a green tween. For a Symbol tween you would use a Classic Tween or Motion Tween. For more information, see topics, Classic Tween or Motion Tween.
question_2: Does Flash support shape tween?
answert_2: Shape tweening can also create some interesting effects when a drawing is turned into a shape, text, or another drawing.  Motion tweens can be used to create motion over a curved line as well. Tween animation in Adobe Flash CS4 is relatively easy to use. Just insert your tween of choice in between two keyframes.
question_3: What is the difference between motion tween and shape tween in Flash?
answert_3: Tweening in Flash The important difference between motion tweening and shape tweening is that motion tweening works on groups and symbols, where shape tweening requires editable objects. You can change any of the object's propertiessize, color, locationas you would in motion tweening.
question_4: What is the purpose of shape tween?
answert_4: In shape tweening, you draw a vector shape at one specific frame in the Timeline. And, change that shape or draw another shape at another specific frame. Animate then interpolates the intermediate shapes for the frames in between, creating the animation of one shape morphing into another.
question_5: What are the advantages to using a shape tween in an animation?
answert_5: The pros for tweening are faster development time and a smaller file size, the cons are less control over your animation and more of a non-realistic look. So, we learn the more control you have over your animation, the more you sacrifice in time and file size.
question_6: What is the difference between a motion tween and shape tween?
answert_6: Motion tweening is used to change the position of an object over time. Shape tweening is used to change the shape of an object.
question_7: How do you use shape tween in Adobe Flash?
answert_7: Choose Insert x26gt; Shape Tween. Animate interpolates the shapes in all the frames between the two keyframes. To preview the tween, scrub the playhead across the frames in the Timeline, or press the Enter key. To tween motion in addition to shape, move the shape in frame 30 to different location from frame 1.
question_8: Does Flash have motion tween?
answert_8: There are two types of Tweens in Flash, Shape Tweens, which can only operate on drawing objects, and Motion Tweens, which can only operate on Symbols. Shape tweens allow you to mutate from one drawing object to another drawing object with different properties or at a different location on the stage.
question_9: What is difference between shape tweening and motion tweening?
answert_9: Answer: The important difference between motion tweening and shape tweening is that motion tweening works on groups and symbols, where shape tweening requires editable objects. Shape tweening doesn't restrict you to changing the object's shape.

question_1: How many chapters does Shantaram have?
answert_1: Like Marmite, or Vegemite - another Australian export - you either loved this book or hated it. I hated it. I really, really hated it. It was a waste of my life enduring five chapters of this egotistical drivel by someone who thought their life was 933-pages worth of importance.
question_2: What happened at the end of Shantaram?
answert_2: He decides that he must fight for what he believes is right, and build an honest life. The story ends with him planning to go to Sri Lanka, which lays the premise for the sequel to this book.
question_3: Who sent Lin to jail in Shantaram?
answert_3: A Bombay crime lord named Abdel Khader Khan takes Lin under his wing, gradually pulling him into his gang. One night, after he finally gets to make love to Karla, Lin is arrested and sent to prison where he's treated horribly. Khader gets Lin out of jail after some time, and Lin starts working for him full time.
question_4: Who betrayed Lin Shantaram?
answert_4: It seems that Karla, Lisa's friend, used her or betrayed her in a sick game with Madame Zhou's customers.

question_6: Is Shantaram an easy read?
answert_6: Shantaram by Gregory David Roberts, for its ability to make me realise the world is not black and white. That hope, compassion and wisdom can sometimes emerge from what the world has hastily labelled wrong or immoral. It is not an easy read

question_9: What happened to Modena in Shantaram?
answert_9: It turns out that Modena had given her the stolen money, and that Maurizio had come to the hotel where they were to get it. Maurizio tortured Modena, but after not finding Ulla or the money, left the scene. When it was all over, Ulla fled and left Modena tied to the bed.
question_10: Is Karla in Shantaram real?
answert_10: If you meant to establish whether Karla or Khader Khan are real people leading lives in India or nearby, sadly(and disappointingly) that's not true. The characters, their names and their stories are entirely fictional, ..as they are in any novel.
question_11: Was Shantaram a true story?
answert_11: David Gregory Roberts calls Shantaram a novel, but it is strongly autobiographical, concentrating on his life in Bombay from 1981 to 1987. Some characters have been disguised or blended, but he insists that the key events are authentic.
question_12: What is the story of Shantaram?
answert_12: Shantaram is the story of an Australian character named Lindsay (Lin). Sentenced to a long, harsh prison term after his personal life spirals out of control, he escapes and makes his way to Bombay (Mumbai). Befriended by a curious character named Prabaker, by a twist of fate Lin ends up living in Prabaker's slum.
question_13: How did Gregory David Roberts get caught?
answert_13: It seems that Karla, Lisa's friend, used her or betrayed her in a sick game with Madame Zhou's customers.
question_14: Was Prabhakar real Shantaram?
answert_14: In time, the European police learned of his true identity and arrested him. He escaped from custody twice more, in Italy and Switzerland, before returning to Bombay. While smuggling drugs in Europe, Roberts was captured by Frankfurt authorities and imprisoned.
question_15: Who is Karla Shantaram?
answert_15: Karla Saaranen, a mysterious and beautiful Swiss woman that Lin meets early in his life in Bombay, turns out to be a very important figure in his adventure. Sexy, smart, and very popular, Karla is liked by everyone in the Bombay expat community, but doesn't seem to be too close to anyone.
question_16: Who set Lin up in Shantaram?
answert_16: A Bombay crime lord named Abdel Khader Khan takes Lin under his wing, gradually pulling him into his gang.
question_17: Is the book Shantaram a true story?
answert_17: Prabhakar Kisan Khare was a real-life individual, as are the members of Khare family from the book (Kisan, Rukhma, Kishor and Parvati Khare) whose names appear on government issued identity cards. The family resides in the Navy Nagar slum where the lead character Shantaram also lived.

question_1: What is the meaning of Shakespeare's Sonnet 116?
answert_1: Summary: Sonnet 116 This sonnet attempts to define love, by telling both what it is and is not. In the first quatrain, the speaker says that lovethe marriage of true mindsis perfect and unchanging; it does not admit impediments, and it does not change when it find changes in the loved one.
question_2: What does Sonnet 116 say about love?
answert_2: In 'Sonnet 116: Let me not to the marriage of true minds,'Shakespeare's speaker is ruminating on love. He says that love never changes, and if it does, it was not true or real in the first place. He compares love to a star that is always seen and never changing.
question_3: What does although his height be taken mean?
answert_3: 65). Whose worth's unknown, although his height be taken (8): The subject here is still the north star. The star's true value can never truly be calculated, although its height can be measured. Love's not Time's fool (9): i.e., love is not at the mercy of Time.
question_4: What does Shakespeare mean by wandering bark?
answert_4: A wandering bark would be a small ship that has lost its way. The poet is saying that just as lost ships can look to the North Star to be able to find direction, lost souls can look to true love as a fixed permanent point from which to find direction and purpose in their lives.
question_5: How does Shakespeare describe true love in Sonnet 116?

question_6: What is most likely the theme in Shakespeare's Sonnet 116?

question_7: What type of love is in Sonnet 116?

question_8: What are the characteristics of true love in Sonnet 116?

question_9: How does Shakespeare see true love in Let me not to the marriage?

question_1: What is the meaning of Sonnet 123?

question_2: What is the tone of Sonnet 123?

The English or Shakespearean sonnet is made up of three quatrains, or sets of four lines, and one concluding couplet, or set of two rhyming lines.

question_18: What is the message of Sonnet 27?
answert_18: Sonnet 27 specifically focuses on the obsessive, restless side of love and infatuation: the speaker is trying to sleep after a long, exhausting day, but his mind won't let him rest. Instead, he's kept awake by thoughts of his absent beloved.
question_19: What is the theme of this sonnet?
answert_19: Shakespeare uses Sonnet 18 to praise his beloved's beauty and describe all the ways in which their beauty is preferable to a summer day. The stability of love and its power to immortalize someone is the overarching theme of this poem.

answert_21: When the poet writes in Sonnet 24 of finding where your true image pictured lies, he focuses on a meaning of true in the sense of genuine as opposed to counterfeit. The young man's beauty is often cast as a shape or appearance.
question_22: Shall you pace forth your praise shall still find room Even in the eyes of all posterity?
answert_22: That's when the Last Judgment or ending doom wraps things up with a rousing final act. In Christian theology, the Last Judgment is like a major trial of everyone's soul. The verdicts: heaven if you're good, and hell if you're bad. In either case, your body gets to be reunited with its soul (yay) and death is over.
question_23: What does the phrase the ending Doom line 12 refer?
answert_23: Personification: Personification is to give human qualities to inanimate objects. Shakespeare has used this device at many places in the poem such as; When wasteful war shall statues overturn and And broils root out the work of masonry.
question_24: What figurative language is used in Sonnet 55?
answert_24: Summary: Sonnet 116 This sonnet attempts to define love, by telling both what it is and is not. In the first quatrain, the speaker says that lovethe marriage of true mindsis perfect and unchanging; it does not admit impediments, and it does not change when it find changes in the loved one.
question_25: What is the meaning of Shakespeare's Sonnet 116?
answert_25: Sonnet 55 is all about the endurance of love, preserved within the words of the sonnet itself. It will outlive material things such as grand palaces, royal buildings and fine, sculptured stone; it will outlive war and time itself, even to judgement day.

question_1: What is the meaning of Sonnet 145?
answert_1: Sonnet 145 is one of Shakespeare's sonnets. It is also the Shakespeare sonnet which uses the fewest letters. It is written as a description of the feelings of a man who is so in love with a woman that hearing her say that she hates something immediately creates a fear that she is referring to him.
question_2: What is Shakespeare's darkest sonnet?
answert_2: Also known as the Black Sonnets, the Dark Lady Sonnets are numbers 127152. In sonnet 127, the dark lady enters the narrative and instantly becomes the object of the poet's desire.
question_3: What is the main idea of Sonnet 141?
answert_3: Sonnet 141 is the informal name given to the 141st of William Shakespeare's 154 sonnets. The theme of the sonnet is the discrepancy between the poet's physical senses and wits (intellect) on the one hand and his heart on the other
question_4: What is the saddest Shakespeare sonnet?
answert_4: Tired with all these, for restful death I cry (Sonnet 66) by William Shakespeare - Poems | poets.org.
question_5: What is Sonnet 145 by Sor Juana about?
answert_5: As the sequel to the previous sonnet, Sonnet 145 is a trivial treatment of love. The mistress grants pity on the poet in contrast to previous sonnets, in which she was merciless. Before, her only words to the poet were I hate, but once she sees how he languished for her sake, her hatred turns into mercy.
question_6: What attitude toward the body and the soul is expressed in sonnet 146?
answert_6: The speaker of this sonnet feels trapped by his preoccupation with his outward appearance, and urges himselfby addressing his neglected soul, which he concedes has the decision-making power over the bodyto neglect the body as a way to enrich the soul and help it toward heaven (Buy terms divine in selling hours of
question_7: What is the message of Sonnet 144?
answert_7: Sonnet 144,'also known as 'Two loves I have of comfort and despair,'expresses the speaker's fears in regard to the Fair Youth's purity. The poem is concerned with how he may be corrupted by the Dark Lady. 'Sonnet 144u2032 is one of William Shakespeare's 154 sonnets.
question_8: What is a Dark Lady sonnet?
answert_8: Tired with all these, for restful death I cry (Sonnet 66) by William Shakespeare - Poems | poets.org.
question_9: Is Sonnet 130 about a black woman?
answert_9: The Dark Lady is a woman described in Shakespeare's sonnets (sonnets 127152) and so called because the poems make it clear that she has black wiry hair and dark, brown, dun coloured skin. The distinction is commonly made in the introduction to modern editions of the sonnets.
question_10: What is the meaning of Sonnet 127?
answert_10: Most of Shakespeare's sonnets are addressed to a young man, but towards the end of the sequence there emerges the so-called Dark Lady, a woman with whom he seems to have had an often difficult and unhappy relationship. Sonnet 130 refers to her, even though we do not know her name. This is an unconventional love poem.
question_11: Who is speaking in Sonnet 141?
answert_11: Sonnet 141 is addressed to the so called Dark Lady, the mistress, the subject of Shakespeare's final 28 sonnets of the complete 154 sonnet sequence.
question_12: What is the theme or main idea of his sonnets?
answert_12: Shakespeare begins his sonnets by introducing six of his most important themesbeauty, time, decay, immortality, procreation and selfishness, which are interrelated in sonnet 1 both thematically and through the use of images associated with business or commerce[3].
question_13: What is the main idea of Sonnet 116?
answert_13: Sonnet 116 develops the theme of the eternity of true love through an elaborate and intricate cascade of images. Shakespeare first states that love is essentially a mental relationship; the central property of love is truththat is, fidelityand fidelity proceeds from and is anchored in the mind.
question_14: What is the central idea of Sonnet 14?
answert_14: The main theme of Sonnet 14 is the eternal nature of love. It is not eternal, says the poet, if one lover loves the other for earthly, temporal reasons. These reasons she details in lines 3-12. Earthly reasons fade, as do human beings.

question_21: What kind of sonnet format does De La Cruz Use *?
answert_21: In form, it is a Petrarchan sonnet, consisting of fourteen lines in two quatrains and two tercets; it uses an abba, abba, cdc, dcd rhyme scheme. Many commentators have noted marked similarity in form and themes to a 1582 sonnet by Spain's Luis de Gxf3ngora y Argote.

question_23: Why does the poet call soul poor soul?
answert_23: In the first line of 'Sonnet 146,'the speaker begins by addressing his Poor soul. It has to contend with a great deal, including the speaker's continual focus on the exterior world. He knows it's wrong of him to spend so much time worrying about earthly pleasures, but he can't help it.
question_24: What is the attitude of love expressed in Sonnet 130?
answert_24: This poem reveals an ambiguous kind of love, one that seems heartfelt and sincere, but also tinged with a kind of harsh anger. The conflict between these two feelings is never fully resolved.
question_25: Where does the turn occur in Sonnet 146?
answert_25: Sonnet 146's turn comes at line 9, where the speaker stops lecturing his soul about being such a chump and tells it how it can turn things around.

question_1: Who started Shaka Samvat?
answert_1: It is believed that the Saka Era was founded by King Kanishka in 78 AD. The Sakas, also known as Shakas in the first century, invaded NorthWest India.
question_2: What is Saka and Vikram Samvat?
answert_2: Shaka Samvat is India's national calendar. This Samvat was started 78 BC whereas Vikram Samvat started in 57 BC. In the same way, the names of months of Shaka and Vikram Samvat are the same, and both the Samvat also have Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha.
question_3: When did Shaka Samvat begin?

question_4: What is the meaning of Shaka Samvat?
answert_4: The Shaka era (IAST: u015aaka, u015au0101ka) or Shalivahana u015aaka is a historical calendar era (year numbering), the epoch (its year zero) of which corresponds to Julian year 78.
question_5: Who started shalivahana Shaka?
answert_5: 1957.National Calendar of India Saka Calendar.Saka SamvatGregorian CalendarVaishakhaApril 21-May 21JyeshthaMay 22-June 21AshadhaJune 22- July 22ShravanaJuly 23-August 228 more rows
question_6: What is Saka Samvat and Vikram Samvat?
answert_6: Key Difference: Saka Samvat and Vikram Samvat are two commonly used calendars in India. Saka Samvat has been adopted as an official civil calendar by India. Saka Samvat starts from 78 AD, whereas Vikram Samvat starts from 57 BC. Thus, samvat as a term can be used to refer to any of the various hindu calendars.
question_7: What is Vikram Samvat in astrology?
answert_7: Vikram Samvat meaning a Lunar Calendar based on ancient tradition and 56.7 years ahead of the Solar Gregorian Calendar. According to the southern (Purnimanta), it is believed to have started in 56 BCE and in the northern (Amanta) in 57-56 BCE. The Shukla Paksha in both coincide, and most festivals occur in this era.
question_8: Why it is called Vikram Samvat?
answert_8: The Shaka era (IAST: u015aaka, u015au0101ka) or Shalivahana u015aaka is a historical calendar era (year numbering), the epoch (its year zero) of which corresponds to Julian year 78.
question_9: When did Shaka Samvat start?
answert_9: The beginning of the Shaka era is now widely equated to the ascension of king Chashtana in 78 CE. His inscriptions, dated to the years 11 and 52, have been found at Andhau in Kutch region. These years are interpreted as Shaka years 11 (89 CE) and 52 (130 CE).
question_10: Who started Shaka Samvat and when?
answert_10: It is believed that the Saka Era was founded by King Kanishka in 78 AD. The Sakas, also known as Shakas in the first century, invaded NorthWest India.
question_11: When did Saka calendar start?
question_12: How is Shaka Samvat calculated?
answert_12: Years are counted in the Saka era, which starts its year 0 in the year 78 of the Common Era. To determine leap years, add 78 to the Saka year if the result is a leap year in the Gregorian calendar, then the Saka year is a leap year as well.
question_13: Who started Saka Samvat?
answert_13: Key Difference: Saka Samvat and Vikram Samvat are two commonly used calendars in India. Saka Samvat has been adopted as an official civil calendar by India. Saka Samvat starts from 78 AD, whereas Vikram Samvat starts from 57 BC. Thus, samvat as a term can be used to refer to any of the various hindu calendars.
question_14: Who invented Shalivahana Shaka?
answert_14: National Calendar of India Saka Calendar The Saka Era is believed to was founded by King Shalivanhana of Shatavahana dynasty. The Saka calendar consists of 365 days and 12 months which is similar to the structure of the Gregorian Calendar.
question_15: Who started shalivahana era?
answert_15: The zero year of Saka era (also Shalivahana era, Sakabda) began in 78 A.D. Kanishka succeeded to the throne of Kushan Empire in 78 A.D. The Christian year 78 A.D. has been accepted by most historians as the year of the foundation of the Saka Era.
question_16: Who started vikrama Shaka?
answert_16: The Vikrama era (58 bc) is said in the Jain book Ku0101laku0101cu0101ryakathu0101 to have been founded after a victory of King Vikramu0101ditya over the u015aaka. But some scholars credit the Scytho-Parthian ruler Azes with the foundation of this era.
question_17: When was started Shalivahana Shaka?
answert_17: The Saka calendar was formed in 79 AD and is based on the crowning of King Shalivaahan in 78 AD, according to a lecturer. The calendar is used alongside the traditional Gregorian Calendar, by The Gazette of India, and in calendars and communications issued by the government of India.
question_18: What is difference between Vikram Samvat and Shaka Samvat?
answert_18: Shaka Samvat is India's national calendar. This Samvat was started 78 BC whereas Vikram Samvat started in 57 BC. In the same way, the names of months of Shaka and Vikram Samvat are the same, and both the Samvat also have Shukla Paksha and Krishna Paksha.
question_19: What is Saka era and Vikram Samvat?

Saka Samvat starts from 78 AD, whereas Vikram Samvat starts from 57 BC. Thus, samvat as a term can be used to refer to any of the various hindu calendars.
question_20: How is Vikram Samvat calculated?
answert_20: The Vikram Samvat uses lunar months and solar sidereal years. Because 12 months do not match a sidereal year, correctional months (adhika mu0101sa) are added or (occasionally) subtracted (kshaya masa).
question_21: What is Vikram Samvat this year?
answert_21: In the year 2022, the first day in the Vikram Samvat calendar falls on 25 October, Tuesday. In the Hindu calendar, this day falls on the first day in the month of Kartik, which is the eighth month in the calendar, having a new moon.

question_1: What is an antithesis in Shakespeare?
answert_1: An antithesis is the setting of one word (or group of words) against another word (or group of words) with an opposite or contrasting meaning. Famous examples of antithesis in Shakespeare are: To be, or not to be. . . His disgrace is to be called boy; but his glory is to subdue men. Fair is foul, and foul is fair. . .
question_2: What is an example of an antithesis?
answert_2: These are examples of antithesis: Man proposes, God disposes. - Source unknown. Love is an ideal thing, marriage a real thing. - Goethe. That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind. - Neil Armstrong.
question_3: How did Shakespeare use antithesis in his writing?
answert_3: Consider William Shakespeare's famous line in Hamlet: Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice. This is a great example of antithesis because it pairs two contrasting ideaslistening and speakingin the same parallel structure. Antithesis is also a great literary device to create rhythm.
question_4: What is the antithesis in Hamlet?
answert_4: Arguably the most famous six words in all of Shakespeare's work are an example of antithesis. Hamlet considers the important question of to be, or not to be. In this line, he is considering the very nature of existence itself. Though the line is quite simple in form it contrasts these very important opposite states.
question_5: What does antithesis mean in poetry?
answert_5: These are examples of antithesis: Man proposes, God disposes. - Source unknown. Love is an ideal thing, marriage a real thing. - Goethe. That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind. - Neil Armstrong.
question_6: What is an antithesis in a sentence?
answert_6: Definition of Antithesis. the total opposite of an object or person. Examples of Antithesis in a sentence. 1. In the movie, Robert's character of an abusive husband is the antithesis of the caring spouse the actor really is.
question_7: What are antithesis words?
answert_7: Antithesis can be defined as a figure of speech involving a seeming contradiction of ideas, words, clauses, or sentences within a balanced grammatical structure. Parallelism of expression serves to emphasize opposition of ideas.

question_10: What effect does antithesis have on the reader?
answert_10: Antitheses are used to strengthen an argument by using either exact opposites or simply contrasting ideas, but can also include both. They typically make a sentence more memorable for the reader or listener through balance and emphasis of the words.
