question_1: What happens in Act 2 of Shakespeare?
answert_1: Romeo enters and Friar Lawrence intuits that Romeo has not slept the night before. The friar fears that Romeo may have slept in sin with Rosaline. Romeo assures him that did not happen, and describes his new love for Juliet, his intent to marry her, and his desire that the friar consent to marry them that very day.
question_2: What happened in Act 2 scene?
answert_2: Romeo reveals himself, agreeing to forsake the name Romeo if he can have her love. Juliet warns him that, as a Montague, he'll be killed if he's spotted with her, but Romeo doesn't care. After much discussion, the two swear their love for each other and agree to be married.
question_3: What happened in Act 2 Macbeth?
answert_3: Act II opens with Banquo and his son, Fleance, making their way to bed in Macbeth's castle. After Fleance and Banquo leave, Macbeth is alone on stage. In one of the most famous soliloquys in the play, Macbeth sees a hallucination of the dagger, seeming to point the way toward Duncan's murder.
question_4: What was Act 2 of Romeo and Juliet about?
answert_4: Juliet, musing to herself and unaware that Romeo is in her garden, asks why Romeo must be Romeoa Montague, and therefore an enemy to her family. Romeo begins to swear to her, but she stops him, concerned that everything is happening too quickly. He reassures her, and the two confess their love again.
question_5: What is a summary of Act 2 in Romeo and Juliet?
answert_5: Romeo enters and Friar Lawrence intuits that Romeo has not slept the night before. The friar fears that Romeo may have slept in sin with Rosaline. Romeo assures him that did not happen, and describes his new love for Juliet, his intent to marry her, and his desire that the friar consent to marry them that very day.
question_6: How does Act 2 End Romeo and Juliet?
answert_6: After a brief moment with her Nurse, Juliet comes back and she and Romeo agree to marry. Juliet tells Romeo she will send him a message so that he can inform her of the wedding plans then exits the scene.
question_7: What are the main events in Act 2 of Romeo and Juliet?
answert_7: Terms in this set (5) Juliet proposes marriage. Friar Lawrence agrees to marry Romeo and Juliet that afternoon. Tybalt sends a letter to Romeo that he is out for revenge for the Montagues crashing the party. Romeo and Juliet married in secret by Friar Lawrence.
question_8: What happened in Act II Scene II?
answert_8: Romeo sees Juliet standing on a balcony and listens to her for a while before announcing his love for her. Without knowing that Romeo can hear her, Juliet laments the fact that Romeo is a Montague. Once he reveals himself, she declares her love for him and agrees to marry him.
question_9: What happens in Act 2 scene of Romeo and Juliet?
answert_9: Lesson Summary In Act 2, Scene 2 of Romeo and Juliet, Romeo sneaks into the orchard that has a view of Juliet's window and professes his love for her though she cannot hear him. Then, she appears at her window and professes her love for him, not knowing that he is there.
question_10: What happens in Act 2 scene Macbeth?
answert_10: In this scene, Macbeth returns from murdering Duncan, alarmed that he heard a noise. Lady Macbeth dismisses his fears and sees that he has brought the guards'daggers with him, rather than planting them at the scene of the crime. She tells him to return the daggers but he refuses and Lady Macbeth goes instead.
question_11: What happens at the end of Act 2 Scene 2?
answert_11: Juliet leaves, but returns momentarily. They agree to marry. Juliet promises to send a messenger the next day so that Romeo can tell her what wedding arrangements he has made. The scene concludes as day breaks and Romeo leaves to seek the advice of Friar Laurence.
question_12: Who died in Act 2 of Macbeth?
answert_12: Macduff
question_13: What is the problem in Act 2 Scene 2 of Macbeth?
answert_13: In Act 2 scene 2, Macbeth feels guilty from the act of murder plotted by Lady Macbeth. His feelings made worse by Lady Macbeth feeling no remorse for the act of murder and instead instructing him to wash his hands as a symbol of washing away the guilt.
question_14: What happened in Act 2 Scene 1 Macbeth?
answert_14: Act 2, Scene 1 Macbeth and Banquo are discussing the witches'prophecies once again. Banquo has been dreaming about them, but Macbeth lies and says they've slipped his mind. He then tells Banquo to stick with him, and he'll be rewarded in the future. Banquo agrees, so long as he gets to keep his conscience clear.
question_15: What is Macbeth's conflict in Act 2?
answert_15: In the extract of Act 2 Scene 1, Macbeth is therefore intended to be portrayed as battling an inner conflict of whether or not to follow a route of potential corruption and divine condemnation, or remain in his loyal position as King Duncan s subject .

answert_19: Act II opens with a prologue that does two things. First it points out that Romeo and Juliet's love will be hard because their families are enemies. Second it pokes fun at Romeo for so quickly falling in love with Juliet and completely getting over Rosaline.

question_23: What happens in Act 2 Scene One of Romeo and Juliet?
answert_23: Romeo risks death to meet Juliet again (Act 2 Scene 1) They reveal their mutual love and Romeo leaves, promising to arrange a secret marriage and let Juliet's messenger, her old Nurse, have the details the following morning. question_25: What happens in Act 2 Scene 2 in Julius Caesar?
answert_25: Summary: Act II, scene ii. Caesar wanders through his house in his dressing gown, kept awake by his wife Calpurnia's nightmares. Three times she has called out in her sleep about Caesar's murder. He sends a servant to bid the priests to offer a sacrifice and tell him the results.

question_1: What does Shadows and Tall Trees symbolize?

question_1: What happens in the book Shadow?

answert_19: She wants to ask them for food, so she tries to catch the black wolf's eye. Many years ago, her father had done the same thing, and the wolf had led him to a dead caribou where her father had a feast.
question_20: What did Julie realize was the truth about Naka?
answert_20: She can't wait to visit her in San Francisco. But she's getting used to Barrow. During the winter, Julie discovers that Naka is an alcoholic who hits his wife.
question_21: What are the pups names in Julie of the wolves?
answert_21: Sister, Zing, Zat, and Zit These other four wolves are the pups of the pack (besides Kapu, of course).
question_22: How many characters are in Julie of the wolves?
answert_22: The most important characters in the novel are Julie herself and the wolves four adults and five puppieswho serve as her companions on the tundra. Her father, Kapugen, is present for the most part only in her imagination; through most of the story she believes him to be dead.
question_23: What happened to jello in Julie of the wolves?
answert_23: Jello's No Super-Wolf He ran head down, low to the ground in the manner of a lone wolf. Jello is barely a member of the pack anymore, and because of that, he has trouble getting enough food. So he does the only thing he can do to survive he steals Miyax's pack, with all her food and supplies in it (3.40).
question_24: What does Julie realize after she recovers her Ulo and needles?
answert_24: In many ways, Kapugen has given in to all the modern conveniences that Miyax has managed to resist. He no longer lives by the traditions he kept up at seal camp. But the seal camp Kapugen was the Kapugen Miyax loved. Still, Miyax must return to Kapugen after the death of her bird-friend Tornait.
question_25: What did Miyax discover about her father that devastated her?
answert_25: As she is looking for her pack, what does Miyax come to realize about her needles and her ulo? She realizes that her needles and ulo are very important. With them, she could mend or sew clothes, cook, hunt, make a home and a larder, or even make a sled.

question_1: Why is Kant's philosophy sometimes described as a Copernican revolution?
answert_1: The philosophy of Immanuel Kant (1724-1804) is sometimes called the Copernican revolution of philosophy to emphasize its novelty and huge importance. After Kant, no discussion of reality or knowledge could take place without awareness of the role of the human mind in constructing reality and knowledge.
question_2: Did Kant support revolution?
answert_2: Kant's denial of a right to revolution is famous, but he was an ardent supporter of the spirit of the French revolution.

question_4: Who is the philosopher associated with the Copernican revolution of philosophy?
answert_4: Kant drew a parallel between the Copernican revolution and the epistemology of his new transcendental philosophy, involving two interconnected foundations of his critical philosophy: the epistemology of transcendental idealism and. the moral philosophy of the autonomy of practical reason.

question_6: What is the Copernican turn Kant?

question_7: In what way was Kant's revolution in epistemology similar to Copernicus revolution in astronomy?

question_8: Does Kant support revolution?

question_10: Does Kant support war?
answert_10: So Kant is a just war theorist: he believes morality has a place in international relations and that there are some circumstances and reasons which can morally (and not just prudentially) justify resorting to war.

answert_12: His moral philosophy is a philosophy of freedom. Kant believes that if a person could not act otherwise, then his or her act can have no moral worth. question_12: What is the difference between Suru and Yaru?

question_1: What is the theme of Kanthapura?
answert_1: The theme of Kanthapura is the unification of different Indian castes under a Gandhian system of social justice during the fight against British rule of India. At the beginning of the novel, Kanthapura, a rural Indian village, is divided by caste.
question_2: What is the summary of the novel Kanthapura?
answert_2: Kanthapura is a 1938 novel written by Indian author Raja Rao. It tells the story of Mahatma Gandhi's independence movement from 1919 to 1930, describing its impact on the caste-ridden south Indian village of Kanthapura. The story is narrated by Achakka, an elderly woman from the village's dominant Brahmin caste,
question_3: Is Kanthapura a Gandhian novel?
answert_3: It is not only a political novel, but also a novel which concerns with socio-religious and economic transformation during the struggle for independence. question_1: What does The Castle represent Kafka?
answert_1: The Castle is an allegory for Kafka's nightmare of the unconscious world. K, the protagonist of the novel, finds himself in a vicious circle. He starts his journey into the dark jungle of the Unconscious. The more he tries to get closer to the village and the villagers, the more suspicious they get about him.
question_2: What is the theme of The Castle?
answert_2: In The Castle, the theme of the individual's struggle to fit into society, even as he opposes it, is most likely the primary theme. Scholars have debated the meaning of the Castle itself, as well as the nature of K.'s quest.
question_3: Why is The Castle unfinished?
answert_3: Unfinished not because of Kafka's untimely death, but because of his inability to find a suitable ending, as he explained to his dear friend and literary executor Max Brod.
question_4: Is The Castle by Kafka worth reading?
answert_4: The Castle would help you understand the symbols of Kafka better - to know why his characters behaved as they did. The Castle after The Trial would be the lived experience of a Kafkaesque maze. One who appreciates and feels scarred by that existential crisis would not miss it for the world.
question_5: How does The Castle end Franz Kafka?
answert_5: In The Castle, the theme of the individual's struggle to fit into society, even as he opposes it, is most likely the primary theme. Scholars have debated the meaning of the Castle itself, as well as the nature of K.'s quest.
question_6: Why did Kafka not finish The Castle?
answert_6: Although Kafka never completed The Castle, he did indicate to Brod the ending he envisaged. In it, K., 'the alleged land-surveyor', receives at least partial satisfaction. He does not give up his struggle, but dies of exhaustion.
question_7: Why does the village in The Castle demonize Amalia?
answert_7: Max Brod. Kafka died before he could finish the novel, and it is questionable whether he intended to finish it if he had survived his tuberculosis. Brod heavily edited the work to ready it for publication. His goal was to gain acceptance of the work and the author, not to maintain the structure of Kafka's writing.
question_8: What is the main theme of the Castle of Otranto?
answert_8: The Castle of Otranto, a novel by Horace Walpole, has a fairly straightforward narrative despite a couple of plot twists at the end. The overall theme of the novel is that righteousness, or justice, will always triumph over greed
question_9: What is the meaning of the castle Kafka?
answert_9: The Castle is an allegory for Kafka's nightmare of the unconscious world. K, the protagonist of the novel, finds himself in a vicious circle. He starts his journey into the dark jungle of the Unconscious. The more he tries to get closer to the village and the villagers, the more suspicious they get about him.
question_10: Why does Freida abandon K in the castle?
answert_10: She is a former short-term mistress to Klamm and very distrustful of K.'s motives and eventually evicts K. because of K's insistence on meeting Klamm; she remains infatuated with Klamm.
question_11: Did Kafka finish the castle?
answert_11: Although Kafka never completed The Castle, he did indicate to Brod the ending he envisaged. In it, K., 'the alleged land-surveyor', receives at least partial satisfaction. He does not give up his struggle, but dies of exhaustion.
question_12: Is The Castle unfinished?
answert_12: The Castle is an unfinished novelas Max Brod, Kafka's literary executor, observed, Kafka intended that K.
question_13: Is The Castle finished Kafka?
answert_13: Unlike The Metamorphosis, The Castle was not finished by Kafka during his lifetime. He communicates with his lifelong friend Max Brod first to tell him about the books ending and then to tell him that he no longer wants to finish it and will never return to it while he lives.
question_14: Is The Trial or The Castle better?
answert_14: The Castle is also an improvement from The Trial in many other ways: almost every character in the book has had a difficult past which Kafka uses to evoke pathos;the story is not over-focused on the main character; the quest to reach the remote authority is more elaborate than in The Trial. 2.
question_15: Is reading Kafka worth it?
answert_15: Absolutely. Kafka is/was a brilliant storyteller, the only thing is that you may find his fiction to be a little on the dark side. But if you can relate to a somewhat depressive, reflective, profound scrutiny of the human condition, the stories are engrossing and memorable.
question_16: Is Kafka boring to read?
answert_16: Kafka is easy to read but difficult to understand. The sentences would make sense but the story does not end there..that is a peculiar thing with Kafka.
question_17: Is Franz Kafka boring?
answert_17: I just read The Castle by Franz Kafka, and i was very disappointed. I found the book boring, poorly thought out, and over rated. The plot and dialog felt intentionally slow paced and monotonous , like the entire book was Kafka trying to make a miss-guided proto-existentialist critique of the bureaucracy.
question_18: Is The Castle by Kafka finished?
answert_18: Unfinished not because of Kafka's untimely death, but because of his inability to find a suitable ending, as he explained to his dear friend and literary executor Max Brod.
question_19: What does Castle represent in Kafka's The Castle?
answert_19: Although Kafka never completed The Castle, he did indicate to Brod the ending he envisaged. In it, K., 'the alleged land-surveyor', receives at least partial satisfaction.
question_20: Does K ever make it to The Castle?
answert_20: If The Castle is a quest narrative, it is utterly unlike any previous quest in fiction, because K.never makes it to the castle, even though the castle is right there next to the village.
question_21: What does Castle represent in Kafka The Castle?
answert_21: The Castle is an allegory for Kafka's nightmare of the unconscious world. K, the protagonist of the novel, finds himself in a vicious circle. He starts his journey into the dark jungle of the Unconscious. The more he tries to get closer to the village and the villagers, the more suspicious they get about him.
question_22: Is K actually a land surveyor?
answert_22: Max Brod. Kafka died before he could finish the novel, and it is questionable whether he intended to finish it if he had survived his tuberculosis. Brod heavily edited the work to ready it for publication. His goal was to gain acceptance of the work and the author, not to maintain the structure of Kafka's writing.
question_23: Why is The Castle of Otranto an important book?
answert_23: The Castle of Otranto, novel by Horace Walpole, published under a pseudonym in 1764 (though first editions bear the next year's date). It is considered the first Gothic novel in the English language, and it is often said to have founded the horror story as a legitimate literary form
question_24: What is the summary of castle of Otranto?
answert_24: It tells the story of Manfred, the prince of Otranto, who is keen to secure the castle for his descendants in the face of a mysterious curse. The novel begins with the death of Manfred's son, Conrad, who is crushed to death by an enormous helmet on the morning of his wedding to the beautiful princess Isabella.
question_25: What does the castle represent in The Castle of Otranto?
answert_25: In The Castle of Otranto, a story centered around a particular castle, the castle represents evil in the form of sexual deviancy and the corruption of power. It is in the castle's eerie rooms and dark passageways that Manfred pursues Isabella, intending to rape her.

question_1: What does Kahlil Gibran say about time?
answert_1: by Khalil Gibran And he answered: You would measure time the measureless and the immeasurable. You would adjust your conduct and even direct the course of your spirit according to hours and seasons. Of time you would make a stream upon whose bank you would sit and watch its flowing.
question_2: What is Khalil Gibran central message in the poem Love?
answert_2: In On Love, Kahlil Gibran shows his ideas about love. The theme of this prose poetry is love, which is although present in different forms, is nonetheless still love. Gibran supports this theme by providing many examples of different types of love and how we should deal with love. He just states how it is.
question_3: Was Kahlil Gibran a mystic?
answert_3: Gibran's undying fame, however, rests as a great poet, thinker and mystic writer. He believed in the essential divinity of human being and the continuity of life. Most of his writings were done originally in Arabic and later translated into English either by himself or by others.
question_4: What is the message of freedom by Kahlil Gibran?
answert_4: Freedom comes from mindfulness and self-compassion Rather, Gibran urges us in his poem On Freedom towards an inner freedomone in which, to paraphrase Harvard psychologist and researcher Robert Kegan, we have our cares, wants, and griefs instead of letting them have us.
question_5: What is the message of the Prophet by Kahlil Gibran?
answert_5: The Prophet provides timeless spiritual wisdom on a range of subjects, including giving, eating and drinking, clothes, buying and selling, crime and punishment, laws, teaching, time, pleasure, religion, death, beauty and friendship.
question_6: What is Kahlil Gibran's central message in the poem Love?
answert_6: In On Love, Kahlil Gibran shows his ideas about love. The theme of this prose poetry is love, which is although present in different forms, is nonetheless still love. Gibran supports this theme by providing many examples of different types of love and how we should deal with love. He just states how it is.
question_7: What is considered the greatest work of Khalil Gibran?
answert_7: Books: 'The Prophet In 1923, Gibran published what became his most famous work, The Prophet. Centered on the character of Almustafa, a holy man set to return home after 12 years in exile, the book expounds on matters of love, sorrow and religion over 26 poetic essays.
question_8: What do you think is Khalil's point of view about marriage?
answert_8: All in all, the concept of marriage according to Kahlil Gibran seems to be that marriage should be a means for the individual growth of its participants. He warms against one person giving or expecting too much. Human beings should feel free to love, free to move about in their relationships.
question_9: What did Kahlil Gibran write a poem about?
answert_9: Gibran drew a following for his prose poems, which were more accessible than traditional Arabic works and explored themes of loneliness and a loss of connection to nature. He published a pamphlet on his love for music in 1905, and followed with two collections of short stories.
question_10: What religion is the Prophet by Kahlil Gibran?
answert_10: The Prophet provides timeless spiritual wisdom on a range of subjects, including giving, eating and drinking, clothes, buying and selling, crime and punishment, laws, teaching, time, pleasure, religion, death, beauty and friendship.
question_11: What are the mystical elements illustrated in Gibran's The Prophet?
answert_11: Inspiration. Though born a Maronite, Gibran was influenced not only by his own religion but also by the Bahxe1'xed Faith, Islam, and the mysticism of the Sufis.
question_12: What is on freedom about?
answert_12: An orator asks about freedom, and Almustafa observes that he has seen them worshipping freedom like slaves do a tyrant. Freedom is a yoke and handcuff. It makes Almustafa's heart bleed to see freedom regarded as anything but a goal and fulfillment.
question_13: What is the message of the poem the prophet on giving?
answert_13: In On Love, Kahlil Gibran shows his ideas about love. The theme of this prose poetry is love, which is although present in different forms, is nonetheless still love. Gibran supports this theme by providing many examples of different types of love and how we should deal with love. He just states how it is.
question_14: What do you think is the advice on love according to what the prophet said in on love?
answert_14: Those who give with joy are rewarded with joy. Those who give with pain are baptized in that pain. Those who give with none of these motivations make God smile on the earth. It is good to give when asked, but it is better to give when unasked, open-handedly, withholding nothing.

question_1: Who is Kabuo Miyamoto?
answert_1: Kabuo Miyamoto is a fisherman and the husband of Hatsue Miyamoto. Kabuo is accused of the murder of Carl Heine, another local fisherman. Kabuo struggles with anger and the power of fate throughout the novel.
question_2: How does the author characterize Kabuo Miyamoto?
answert_2: Like Carl Heine, Kabuo is a victim of fate. He does not feel that his fate is entirely arbitrary, however. A conscientious and pensive man, Kabuo feels guilty about killing Germans in World War II, even though he was merely doing his duty as a soldier.
question_3: How does Guterson characterize Miyamoto?
answert_3: In this novel, Guterson describes Kabuo Miyamoto as a unique person. Kabuo is a Japanese American character who has faced a lot of experience in his life. One of his experiences is being a soldier who fights for America in World War II, though he himself is Japanese.
question_4: Why is Kabuo Miyamoto on trial?
answert_4: On San Piedro Island, located off the coast of mainland Washington in the Pacific Northwest, a Japanese-American fisherman named Kabuo Miyamoto goes on trial for the murder of Carl Heine, a well-liked local fisherman and respected war veteran.

answert_13: Snowand more specifically, the snowstorm that unfolds over the course of Kabuo Miyamoto's murder trialrepresents all that is beyond the ability of humans to control.
question_14: What is the story Snow Falling on Cedars about?
answert_14: Set on the fictional San Piedro Island in the Strait of Juan de Fuca, just north of Puget Sound, in the state of Washington in 1954, the plot revolves around a murder case in which Kabuo Miyamoto, a Japanese American, is accused of killing Carl Heine, a respected fisherman in the close-knit community.
question_15: What is the central conflict of the novel Snow Falling on Cedars?
answert_15: major conflict Kabuo Miyamoto stands trial for the murder of Carl Heine, while Ishmael Chambers struggles to overcome his emotionally and physically shattered past.
question_16: Who are the main characters in Snow Falling on Cedars?

question_17: What was found on Carl's boat?
answert_17: Art testifies that Carl Heine's boat, the Susan Marie, was found adrift on the morning of September 16, 1954. Upon boarding the boat and investigating the scene, Art and his deputy, Abel Martinson, found Carl's body trapped in the boat's fishing net underwater.
question_18: What bothers Hatsue most about her relationship with Ishmael?
answert_18: Hatsue's emotional reserve often upset Ishmael, but she always justified it by claiming that her parents had trained her to avoid emotional displays. Though she cared about Ishmael, Hatsue was deeply bothered that her relationship with him required her to deceive her parents constantly.
question_19: When kabuo boards Carl's boat What does kabuo loan Carl?
answert_19: Kabuo tells Nels that he answered a distress signal from Carl's boat. One of Carl's batteries had run out of power, so the two fishermen tied their boats together and Kabuo loaned Carl a D-6 battery
question_20: Who is the antagonist in Snow Falling on Cedars?
answert_20: The antagonists of Snow Falling on Cedars are the racial hatred, prejudice, and bigotry that exist quietly or openly in the hearts of many of the islanders. These traits are particularly manifested in Etta Heine, who openly shows her prejudice.
question_21: Why is the Snow Falling on Cedars a banned book?
answert_21: 2001 - Washington - 150 South Kitsap parents claimed the book was pornography and the school board admitted it contained sexual content and profanity, banning the book. The town opposed the ban. 2003-4 - California - Challenged but retained in Modesto for sexual content and scenes of war.

question_24: What is the symbolic meaning of the cedar tree in Snow Falling on Cedars?
answert_24: The cedar tree represents the absence of society's pressures and prejudices. As young lovers, Ishmael Chambers and Hatsue Imada retreat to the haven of a hollow cedar tree to be together in a prejudiced society that won't permit their interracial relationship.
question_25: What is the significance of the novel's last sentence accident ruled every corner of the universe except the chambers of the human heart?
answert_25: The last sentence of the novel: accident ruled every corner of the universe except the chambers of the human heart explains the lack of control that humans have on the forces surrounding them compared to the control they have over their actions or decisions and the impact that it has.

question_20: What exactly is hibachi?
answert_20: Hibachi grills are called shichirin in Japanese and are small, portable barbecue grills that are made from cast iron. The word hibachi means fire bowl and refers to the cylindrical shape of the container, which has an open top and is designed to burn wood or charcoal.
question_21: What is a hibachi dinner?
answert_21: Hibachis are a small type of grill heated by charcoal or wood, while teppan grills are flat-top grills heated by gas. Essentially, both terms refer to the Benihana-style restaurant experience where a chef cooks your grilled meal right in front of you, and dinner often includes a culinary show.

answert_6: the ancient ruins
question_7: Where did Baloo and Bagheera find Kaa?
answert_7: Baloo is upset he didn't warn Mowgli about the dangers of the Monkey People sooner. He and Bagheera go to find Kaa the rock python, who is 30 feet long, to ask him for help rescuing Mowgli. They know Kaa is the only creature the Bandar-log fear.
question_8: Where did Bandar-log took Mowgli?
answert_8: the Rain Forest
question_9: What is Bandar-log in Jungle Book?
answert_9: monkeys
question_10: Why are the Bandar-log considered as outcasts?
answert_10: The Bandar-Log, or Monkey People, are a group of monkeys that do not follow the Law of the Jungle, have no leader, and are considered outcasts of the Jungle. They also don't fear anything, exept for Kaa the python.
question_11: What did Baloo say about the Bandar-log people?
answert_11: Monkeys can travel fast when they want to, and by now Baloo and Bagheera were a long way behind. 'We cannot follow the Bandar-log through the trees,'said Baloo, 'and we will never catch them.
question_12: What did Kaa do in front of the monkeys?
answert_12: Kaa went softly out in front of the lines of sitting monkeys and began to dance. His head moved from right to left, and his long body turned this way and that way, making circles that changed every second. Slowly, never hurrying, Kaa danced in front of the monkeys. Baloo and Bagheera stood and could not move.
question_13: Why did Kaa try to eat Mowgli?
answert_13: Although he only hypnotized Mowgli when he was sure Bagheera was too sleepy to notice him, it was his own cockiness that woke the panther and made him lose his supper. He can be clumsy and easily sidetracked from his primary objective: to hypnotize and eat Mowgli.
question_14: Who saves Mowgli from the Bandar-log?
answert_14: The Bandar-log kidnap Mowgli following his hunting exercise on Tabaqui's command so Shere Khan could kill him, but are thwarted by Bagheera, Baloo, and Kaa.
question_15: Who taught Mowgli the stranger hunting call?
answert_15: Baloo
question_16: Why did Mowgli need to learn the law of the jungle?
answert_16: Explanation: Mowgli, being a man-cub, is taught all of the Laws of the Jungle because they all apply to him. Baloo teaches Mowgli the Wood and Water Laws, most of which involve basic manners for all species in the jungle and how to ensure his presence in the jungle is not disruptive or a nuisance.
question_17: What did Bagheera teach Mowgli?
answert_17: Bagheera, the panther, taught Mowgli to hunt and how to move silently in the jungle. He would sometimes lie beneath a tree and Mowgli would try and creep up on him without being heard.
question_18: What is the moral of Mowgli story?
answert_18: The most important life lesson in Jungle Book is to not be a coward. We need to face our fears, gain confidence, and triumph over it. This is shown beautifully when Mowgli faces the Tiger - Shere Khan and saves his friend Baloo. Jungle Book also tells us how to lead a simple and happy life.
question_19: Where does Mowgli legend of the jungle take place?
answert_19: colonial India
question_20: Is Mowgli Indian?
answert_20: Mowgli, fictional character, an Indian boy raised by wolves who is the central figure in Rudyard Kipling's collection of children's stories included in The Jungle Book (1894) and its sequel (1895).
question_21: Is The Jungle Book set in a rainforest?
answert_21: The Jungle Book is the story of Mowgli, a little Indian boy raised by wolves who ends up all alone in the rainforest. The Indian rainforest in this film is often a dark and dangerous place, but the movie doesn't tell the dark story author Rudyard Kipling wrote a century ago.
question_22: Is Jungle Book based on a true story?
answert_22: The story from Jungle Book isn't fiction. It's based on a real person, a real man-cub. When Rudyard Kipling wrote the Jungle Book in 1894, few understood where his inspiration originated from. The story follows the journey of a wild boy called Mowgli, who grew up among wolves without any human contact.
question_23: Where did the monkeys put Mowgli?
answert_23: The Jungle Book The monkeys take Mowgli to their king at the ancient ruins. King Louie offers to let Mowgli stay in the Jungle if he can teach him (King Louie) how to make fire through the song I Wanna Be Like You.
question_24: Where did the Bandar-log take Mowgli?
answert_24: In the Book Mowgli had been playing the Bandar Log and was told not to by Bagheera and Baloo. However, shortly afterwards, Mowgli is abducted by the Bandar Log. The Bandar Log then take their prisoner to their hideout, the Cold Lairs
question_25: Why did the monkeys kidnap Mowgli?
answert_25: The Bandar-log kidnap Mowgli following his hunting exercise on Tabaqui's command so Shere Khan could kill him, but are thwarted by Bagheera, Baloo, and Kaa.

question_10: Why does phosphoric acid have 3 pKa?
answert_10: Polyprotic acids are capable of donating more than one proton. Because phosphoric acid has three acidic protons, it also has three pKa values.

question_12: What are pKa of acids?
answert_12: In simple terms, pKa is a number that shows how weak or strong an acid is. A strong acid will have a pKa of less than zero. More precisely pKa is the negative log base ten of the Ka value (acid dissociation constant). The lower the value of pKa, the stronger the acid and the greater its ability to donate its protons.

question_17: Is chloric acid a weak acid?
answert_17: All the other acids are weak. The strong acids are hydrochloric acid, nitric acid, sulfuric acid, hydrobromic acid, hydroiodic acid, perchloric acid, and chloric acid. The only weak acid formed by the reaction between hydrogen and a halogen is hydrofluoric acid (HF).
question_18: Is HClO3 a strong acid?

question_6: What is KA and how do you find it?
answert_6: The acid dissociation constant (Ka) is used to distinguish strong acids from weak acids. Strong acids have exceptionally high Ka values. The Ka value is found by looking at the equilibrium constant for the dissociation of the acid. The higher the Ka, the more the acid dissociates.

question_8: What is Ka-be?

question_9: How did Primo Levi survive Auschwitz?

question_17: Can Rosetta Stone count as high school credit?
answert_17: Each Rosetta Stone program equals about a year of high school study or a semester of college study. Rosetta Stone can be used to give credit for high school foreign language study or college study. In the past, you would have to buy the level(s) of Spanish you wanted to study.
question_18: Do online Spanish classes work?
answert_18: Learning Spanish for beginners takes work, but online Spanish classes can be doable and enjoyable.  The Internet is overflowing with apps, videos, and grammar exercises to teach you Spanish. That's fine and dandy, but most people need social experience to develop language skills.
question_19: Is duolingo or Babbel better for Spanish?
answert_19: Main Differences Between Babbel vs Duolingo Babbel is best for learnings looking to completely master a language, whereas Duolingo is better for sporadic learners who want to dabble. How to Learn Spanish by Yourself in 18 Simple Steps
  • Spend an hour a day on grammar exercises from a textbook.

  • Spend time in Spanish-speaking environments.
question_24: Is taking Spanish online hard?
answert_24: Learning Spanish online can be difficult for a lot of people if they are not motivated from within. question_25: How long does it take to learn Spanish online?

question_25: What is Onegin sonnet?
answert_25: The Pushkin Sonnet, also known as the Onegin stanza, is a verse form created by Russian poet and novelist Alexander Pushkin for his novel in verse, Eugine Onegin. question_1: What is a one tailed research hypothesis?
answert_1: A one-tailed test is a statistical hypothesis test set up to show that the sample mean would be higher or lower than the population mean, but not both. Before running a one-tailed test, the analyst must set up a null hypothesis and an alternative hypothesis and establish a probability value (p-value).
question_2: How do you know if a hypothesis is one tailed or two tailed?
answert_2: A one-tailed test has the entire 5% of the alpha level in one tail (in either the left, or the right tail). A two-tailed test splits your alpha level in half (as in the image to the left).
question_3: What is an example of a two tailed hypothesis?
answert_3: For example, let's say you were running a z test with an alpha level of 5% (0.05). In a one tailed test, the entire 5% would be in a single tail. But with a two tailed test, that 5% is split between the two tails, giving you 2.5% (0.025) in each tail.
question_4: What is a one tailed alternative hypothesis?
answert_4: A one-tailed test results from an alternative hypothesis which specifies a direction. i.e. when the alternative hypothesis states that the parameter is in fact either bigger or smaller than the value specified in the null hypothesis.
question_5: How do you know if a hypothesis is one tailed or two-tailed?
answert_5: A one-tailed test has the entire 5% of the alpha level in one tail (in either the left, or the right tail). A two-tailed test splits your alpha level in half (as in the image to the left).
question_6: What is the difference between one tailed and two-tailed?
answert_6: A one-tailed test is used to ascertain if there is any relationship between variables in a single direction, i.e. left or right. As against this, the two-tailed test is used to identify whether or not there is any relationship between variables in either direction.
question_7: How do you know if its a one-tailed test?
answert_7: A one-tailed test will test either if the mean is significantly greater than x or if the mean is significantly less than x, but not both.
question_8: What is the null hypothesis for a one tailed t test?
answert_8: The null hypothesis (H0) for a one tailed test is that the mean is greater (or less) than or equal to xb5, and the alternative hypothesis is that the mean is x26lt; (or x26gt;, respectively) xb5.
question_9: How do you know if a hypothesis is one-tailed?
answert_9: A one-tailed test is a statistical test in which the critical area of a distribution is one-sided so that it is either greater than or less than a certain value, but not both. If the sample being tested falls into the one-sided critical area, the alternative hypothesis will be accepted instead of the null hypothesis.
question_10: How do you know if its a two tailed hypothesis?
answert_10: A two-tailed test will test both if the mean is significantly greater than x and if the mean significantly less than x. The mean is considered significantly different from x if the test statistic is in the top 2.5% or bottom 2.5% of its probability distribution, resulting in a p-value less than 0.05.
question_11: What is the difference between two tailed and one tail?
answert_11: One-tailed tests allow for the possibility of an effect in one direction. Two-tailed tests test for the possibility of an effect in two directionspositive and negative.
question_12: What is a two tailed hypothesis example?
answert_12: A Two Tailed Hypothesis is used in statistical testing to determine the relationship between a sample and a distribution. In statistics you compare a sample (Example: one class of high school seniors SAT scores) to a larger set of numbers, or a distribution (the SAT scores for all US high school seniors).
question_13: What is two tailed one hypothesis?
answert_13: The Basics of a One-Tailed Test Hypothesis testing is run to determine whether a claim is true or not, given a population parameter. A test that is conducted to show whether the mean of the sample is significantly greater than and significantly less than the mean of a population is considered a two-tailed test.
question_14: How do you determine if a hypothesis is two tailed?
answert_14: A two-tailed test will test both if the mean is significantly greater than x and if the mean significantly less than x. The mean is considered significantly different from x if the test statistic is in the top 2.5% or bottom 2.5% of its probability distribution, resulting in a p-value less than 0.05.
question_15: What is the difference between one tailed and two-tailed test?
answert_15: A one-tailed test is used to ascertain if there is any relationship between variables in a single direction, i.e. left or right. As against this, the two-tailed test is used to identify whether or not there is any relationship between variables in either direction.
question_16: Is an alternative hypothesis two-tailed?
answert_16: A two-sided hypothesis is an alternative hypothesis which is not bounded from above or from below, as opposed to a one-sided hypothesis which is always bounded from either above or below. In fact, a two-sided hypothesis is nothing more than the union of two one-sided hypotheses.

question_1: What is the purpose of one writer's beginning?
answert_1: The central purpose of One Writer's Beginning is Welty's exploration of what it is that makes a writer become a writer and what it is that sets a writer apart from others.
question_2: Who is the audience of One Writer's Beginnings?
answert_2: Young readers who aspire to become professional writers or who are interested in how writers and artists think and develop will find Welty's book interesting.
question_3: What is the main purpose of the first three paragraphs listening by Eudora Welty?
answert_3: Welty's pleasure in listening helped her to develop two crucial gifts: an internal voice and an ability to distance herself from events as an observer.
question_4: What is the theme of listening by Eudora Welty?
answert_4: In the first chapter, Listening, Eudora Welty describes her early childhood, which includes her parents'focus on learning and encouraging their children to read. Eudora loves books and reading from a very young age; before beginning to write, she listens for stories instinctively.
question_5: What is One writer's Beginnings by Eudora Welty about?
answert_5: One Writer's Beginnings is a collection of autobiographical essays by Eudora Welty. Welty explains the inescapable bond between her childhood in Mississippi and her later career as a writer. She shares details from her childhood and her relationship with her parents, Christian Welty and Chestina Andrews Welty.

question_1: Is it rude to use Kudasai?
answert_1: Kudasai is not rude in any sense but one does have to be careful with the type of Japanese you use in different situations. You just need to know how to use the Japanese you knoe correctly, who to use them with, and when the appropriate time to use it is.
question_2: What is the meaning of Kudasai?
answert_2: Please
question_3: What can I say instead of Kudasai?
answert_3: Kudasai follows the object and the particle o, like mizu o kudasai. Onegai shimasu can be replaced with kudasai when you want an object. It sounds a little more polite than using 'kudasai'. So you can say, mizu o onegai shimasu.
question_4: Is Choudai polite?
answert_4: Choudai is a casual expression to say 'please'in Japanese and while it can be used by both men and women, it has a feminine nuance. Like most words for 'please'in Japanese, you can modify the politeness by adding honorific stems to choudai.
question_5: Is Kudasai polite?
answert_5: While kudasai is a more familiar term, onegaishimasu is more polite or honorific. Thus, this Japanese word is used when you are requesting a favor. You would also use it if you are directing the request to a superior or to someone you do not know well.

question_16: Where do we use Kudasai?

question_18: How do I use Kudasai and Onegaishimasu?
answert_18: Both kudasai and onegai shimasu are used when making a request for items. Kudasai follows the object and the particle o, like mizu o kudasai. Onegai shimasu can be replaced with kudasai when you want an object. It sounds a little more polite than using 'kudasai'.
question_19: What does onegai mean?

question_20: Is Yamete Kudasai a bad word?
answert_20: This means to stop and there are several versions of this word that is proper to use in different scenarios but if you are in a polite conversation, especially with a person you are talking to for the first time, it would be best to use Yamete kudasai which translates to please stop.
question_21: How do you say Yamete Kudasai in Japanese?
answert_21: The most polite version of these is yamete kudasai. In the Japanese language this is written as u3084u3081u3066 u304fu3060u3055u3044, and means please stop it. People in Japan may use this phrase if they are trying to get a bus or taxi to stop for them.

question_1: Which is correct more than one or more than one?
answert_1: With countable nouns (such as bird/birds,tree/trees, house/houses, person/people, and so forth), it's correct to say There are more and more, because after there is one, more must mean that there are more than one, and thus the noun is plural, and hence are is used.
question_2: Are one or more or is one or more?
answert_2: It is one of the very rare rules in English where the version that sounds better really is right. According to me :- one or more are, it's RIGHT to say because it depends on which verb it is closer to one or more and we see that the more is closer to verb 'ARE'and more is plural word, so we use to plural verb.
question_3: Is people one or more?
answert_3: Persons is often used in formal, legal contexts to emphasize individuals as opposed to a group. People is the plural of person that's most commonly used in everyday communication to simply refer to multiple humans. But people can also be used as a singular noun to refer to a population or particular community.
question_4: Is it one or two or one or two?
answert_4: 8 Answers. It would be grammatically correct to use are if the subjects were indeed two individually, but they are not. By saying One and one are two, that means that each one is two. The equivalent would be, One is two, and one is two.
question_5: Do you say there is more than one or there are more than one?
answert_5: The choice between the phrases there is and there are at the beginning of a sentence is determined by the noun that follows it. Use there is when the noun is singular (There is a cat). Use there are when the noun is plural (There are two cats).
question_6: Which is correct there is more or there are more?
answert_6: It is one of the very rare rules in English where the version that sounds better really is right. question_7: How do you use more than one person?
answert_7: With uncountable nouns (such as water, time, noise, money, sugar, and so forth), it's correct to say There is more and more, because uncountable nouns are treated as singular third-person nouns. Thus, is is used.
question_8: Is one or more are one or more?
answert_8: There is no general agreement on whether or not the phrase one or more should be taken to be singular or plural. The Cambridge Guide to English Usage says: For most writers the choice depends on whether you're thinking of a single case or general principle.
question_9: Is more than one or are more than one?
answert_9: When more than one modifies a singular noun, it goes with a singular verb: More than one person is going. But when it's followed by of and a plural noun, it takes a plural verb: More than one of the people are going.
question_10: Is it more is or more are?
answert_10: More is one of those words that can be either singular or plural: More is coming. More are coming. Another is all, which means you can write All is lost! All are lost! and be correct both times. In practice, the media tend to treat the expression as plural (One out of three players are local boys).
question_11: Is a number of people or are a number of people?
answert_11: Either can be correct! It depends on whether the verb (is or are) refers to the number (singular therefore is) or the people (plural therefore are). Hence: The number of people in Sydney is greater than a million.

question_13: Is it two or two?
answert_13: Onto is a preposition, it implies movement, and is more specific that on. On to are two words, and when paired with each other, on acts as a part of a verbal phrase and to acts as a preposition. You can quickly remember the different by saying up before on/onto.

question_16: Are there or is there more than one?
answert_16: There are is the plural form of there is and there's: There are two new buildings next to the school. They are both science buildings. In speaking and in some informal writing, we use there's even when it refers to more than one.
question_17: Is one or more or are one or more?

question_18: Is it there are many or there is many?
answert_18: Because many suggests more than one, a plural verb is required. Therefore, There are many, is correct.
question_19: Which is correct there is or there are?
answert_19: Use there is when the noun is singular (There is a cat). Use there are when the noun is plural (There are two cats).
question_20: When there is more than one or when there are more than one?
answert_20: When more than one modifies a singular noun, it goes with a singular verb: More than one person is going. But when it's followed by of and a plural noun, it takes a plural verb: More than one of the people are going.
question_21: Which is correct there is a lot or there are a lot?
answert_21: Answer: There's a lot is correct. there're a lot is in no way correct, but you probably meant they're a lot which would also be correct, depending on what you intended to mean. There's a lot There is a lot (of mud). Notice how mud is an amorphous and collective noun, therefore it takes the singular case.
question_22: Is it correct to use more and more?
answert_22: You can use more and more to indicate that something is becoming greater in amount, extent, or degree all the time. Her life was heading more and more where she wanted it to go. Bob became more and more furious. More and more women are wearing men's fragrances.
